content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Don't Starve is one of those games where the only word that justifies it's quality and content is "perfection". It is such a complete experience, it has everything you would want in a survival game, and the level of content is monumentous. The one thing that really makes this game a treasure is the simplicity. What? You might ask. I will try to explain:The UI/ menus are perfectly uncomplex. They are neat, responsive and incredibly easy to navigate as everything is very well organized.The inventory spaces are placed neatly at the bottom of the screen and are always available to you. you have the option of organizing your materials into a few groups with slight spaces between lots of inventory slots. The clicking + dragging mechanism makes this process so much easier. I often organize all my edibles into one group, main building materials into another and tools/ armours/ weapons into another. The crafting system is also very easy to grasp. You can click whatever it is you want to build in the menu to the left and see what kind of resources you need to craft that item, with pictures of the actual items which makes the whole identifying process a breeze. The map is excellent. You can see (as far as you have travelled) key locations such as berry bushes, forests, different biomes e.t.c... You can also see where you've built stuff, if you have. This is very important if you don't want to get lost!The actual physical game map that you travel on is amazing. Resources are easy to find, click and collect. Your main tools (hatchet, pick-axe and shovel) require the most basic resources so you will easily be able to replace them without much hassle. This is also probably the only game where people won't question your pathological excitement over poop.Trust me, you will have so much fun just collecting hordes of resources and then putting them to use and generally just trying to survive another day. The game does get difficult, especially if you have the expansion enabled, which offers a whole new and exciting experience, but even if you fail, you'll want to immediately start again and perhaps learn from your previous mistakes and do things differently. I simply cannot find one negative aspect in this game, it is, as I said before, perfection.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I strongly recommend this game.  Reminds me of Minecraft's first few minutes/hours where you're scraping to stay alive, but this is harder, and more rewarding, minus the building for the most part.  The art style is great, very atmospheric and fun to watch.  Though no in-game instruction is given, the difficulty of picking up on how things work isn't bad, after a couple deaths, you'll know how to progress through the first few days.  That's my one gripe, dying starts you over, with no save game, it automatically deletes it for you.  This lends urgency to your quest to survive, which I like, but the first 3 days or so take half an hour, and there's not much variation in during that time, so it starts to feel a little repetitive.  But after that, there's tons of cool stuff, so it's a minor annoyance.  Also, to be fair, I wouldn't have to play those first three days so many times if I'd just follow the direction, "Don't Starve"

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												One of the most difficult games I've ever played, yet I keep coming back for more. It'd be easy to stop playing out of frustration, the game doesn't teach you anything and you learn simply by doing. With every death means starting over from scratch, the permadeath is both punishing and extremely rewarding to see how far you will get and how you must adjust your strategy in order to survive. The odds are stacked against you, but it never feels unfair. There is always something you could have done better or a different route you could have taken that may have lead to you living longer. Believe it or not you can even beat this game, or so I've heard.Nothing is more satisfying than figuring out a new mechanic while you are playing simply from experimentation, this game is so finely tuned and balanced that it must've been a nightmare for the devs to make. The combat is excellent yet simple and easy to understand, it is really all you could ask for in a Survival Crafting type game. And to make things even better the Multiplayer version of the game is even more fun, although not yet as feature complete as the singleplayer variant.The graphics are simply beautiful and extremely charming, nothing is more adorable than a sleeping homeless spider or a recently shaved beefalo. Add in unlockable characters, an excellent and tweakable world gen, and a plethora of mods on steam and you have a game that is well worth replaying.

												I always wanted to play in survival game where EVERYTHING CAN KILL YOU! :DDied by:- my own weapon? - CHECKED!- my own tools? - CHECKED!- my laziness? - CHECKED!- my stupidity? - CHECKED!...and that is only the beginning of nightmare you going to face.Lets go deeper, shall we? I am still on the Day 1. Yep! Totally worth it!Great game. It has very nice art style, and music. It is gameplay wise, it may seem like other "survival" games out there, but this one is really different. On the first look, you may think "Oh damm.. it is a Minecraft copy", but that opinion is far from truth. On conceptual layer they are both simillar to each other, but on the gameplay leyer they are completely different. They got completely different priorities expected from a player.My Walkthrough Guide:

												Don't Starve and Dwarf Fortress share one thing in common; losing is fun!The game itself is a huge learning experience, and you'll always get further (usually) the last time than you did the first time.  Even if you manage to make a self-sustaining base that was indeed somewhat indestructable, the game would lose a lot of what made it fun to begin with.  Of course, getting to said point requires said experience; which depending on the person may or may not actually come.It's brutal at first glance, but even after you get better; the game doesn't stop getting harder.  If anything, the longer you live, the more merciless nature itself gets.  If you're not prepared, then prepare to die!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												"AH♥♥♥♥♥♥HOUNDS!" i yelled, running through the woods in my attempts to escape the beasts. nearly bled out from making mysterious 2 legged pig men angry. What did i do to deserve this harsh world? Everything is fubat. Tree monsters hide in the forrests, spiders all over the place, insanity growing, hunger rising. Now this. Will this finally be my un-doing? To loose all i have gained onlt to start a life anew in the constantly hostile world. Only comparable to that of a schtizophranic mind. Beasts roam wild and all is dangerous. So few are the safeties of the fire in winter, and so rare is the safety of defences at night. Scavenging was hard enough to survive for the first few weeks. Now im going to die bie these blood thristy hounds of hell, or wherever such beasts were created. WAIT! a hole in the ground! I must get to it in order to survive. I jump down, only into darkness. Insanity is building, i see things in this dark tunnel. What awaits on the otherside? When i awaken my eyes, i am in a land i have yet not seen. My pursuers may not have easily given up, so i must run. Run fast, run far; only that i could if my stomach wasnt so empty, aarg i must have something to eat. Thankfully theres some bushes, but is that....a spiders nest? with little strength left, and a spear in hand, I make the short path to the dangerous bushes. To so i dont allow my self...to dont starve.9/10 for immersion: Very dangerous gameplay, you must be quick to think, or die from the elements of this vast and wierd place. I must say even being experienced in survival games, the night times in here are terrifying and detrimental to your health if you are un prepared to venture fourth in such time.10/10 for creativity: Very different sense of survivalism, if you like turkeys to be hulking 2 legged beasts, and any sort of socialness to be between a living pot following you, and pigmen. This is definitely for you.8/10 mechanics: Simple to use, as simple as click to move, use, everything else you need to know. Though i had alot of problems with picking up items behind other items. Which quickly became a nuissance.

												Combining the aspects of survival, adventure and sandbox into one game full of mystery and wonder makes this well worth playing. Posted: December 1, 2014
												This games lived well past my expectations, with an extraordinary art style, unique game play and tactical. You're not only trying to survive but achieve your best. Each day that passes you scurry off trying to gather as many things as possible and hope that your base is in a safe enough spot. The achievements and points system is easy enough to gain and progress fast. As you explore this vast land you'll encounter creatures, friendly beasts, mysterious entities and the weird, wonderful and scary abilities of Mother Nature and the human body.I'm only on day 13 but I've already built walls, floors, a fire and tools for building and crafting. This game is an experience like no other and is one of the best sandbox style games I've purchased in ages.

												This game is incredible its just like your basic Sandboxish game with the build and stuff but it also has a legimate adventure mode once you make the diving rod and find maxwells portal anywayDont starve has many aspects so you will die eventually (unless you have a crap ton of farms to last you forever)Plus even if you do die you get xp points so you can get a new characterDont starve offers a very simple way to install mods like all steam stuff anyway~And Dont starve never gets old because if you die you still havn't found everything in the game yet.Another mechanic there is in dont starve is the Sanity system and the being afraid of the dark.During night or doing other stuff such as picking evil flowers can reduce your sanity and the lower it getsthe more Ghosts you see that want to kill you,At night if you dont have any light around you,then you'll just die cuz of monsters lurking in the darkEdit: The dlc "Reign of giants" is a great addition for hardcore players who tend to find dont starve too easy and are looking for a better challenge,one thing we would all like to see tho is Multiplayer in either a mod form or just added to the game.Anyway dont starve is a brilliant game and this is the longest review i've written.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Nice little game.  If it was multiplayer, I would say go full price, but you should catch this when it is on sale.  It also includes a second game mode that is worth checking out that plays kind of like the "Slenderman" horror minigame.  It is challenging, at least in the beginning while you are trying to figure out how not to starve to death or get murdered by darkness.  The second character you unlock basically allows you to play endlessly, so if you want a good challenge, try skipping her.  Also, the game seems to ramp up difficulty the more days you survive, which I know sounds typical, but the game lends itself to a feeling of opening new areas for higher difficulty instead of time-based difficulty progression.-It plays like a point and click hack n slash in an open world, but no traditional rpg elements.-The art is cute and works well with the play-style. -Craft to survive.  Bang on a tree to get wood for a fire, build an axe or pick, even a snare to catch dinner.-If you have played DayZ, Rust or one of the other Survival Horror games, then that is what you can expect, but in an isometric, 2D environment which is a refreshing pov shift for a genre I enjoy.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												One of the most difficult games I've ever played, yet I keep coming back for more. It'd be easy to stop playing out of frustration, the game doesn't teach you anything and you learn simply by doing. With every death means starting over from scratch, the permadeath is both punishing and extremely rewarding to see how far you will get and how you must adjust your strategy in order to survive. The odds are stacked against you, but it never feels unfair. There is always something you could have done better or a different route you could have taken that may have lead to you living longer. Believe it or not you can even beat this game, or so I've heard.Nothing is more satisfying than figuring out a new mechanic while you are playing simply from experimentation, this game is so finely tuned and balanced that it must've been a nightmare for the devs to make. The combat is excellent yet simple and easy to understand, it is really all you could ask for in a Survival Crafting type game. And to make things even better the Multiplayer version of the game is even more fun, although not yet as feature complete as the singleplayer variant.The graphics are simply beautiful and extremely charming, nothing is more adorable than a sleeping homeless spider or a recently shaved beefalo. Add in unlockable characters, an excellent and tweakable world gen, and a plethora of mods on steam and you have a game that is well worth replaying.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												For such a simple objective--not starving (or dying by creature, cold, heat, darkness, or other means)--this game is extremely rich and complex.  It has two modes; a sandbox survival mode in which your goal is simply to explore and become self-sustaining, and an adventure mode in which your goal is to overcome harsh environments to complete a machine to move to the next world.  You can play either in the spirit of discovering how to construct, create, and build everything yourself or consult and external reference for help, but either way, you'll be presented with a challenge that will keep you occupied and wanting to go a little further for weeks.  I highly recommend it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												With a title like "Don't Starve", you'd think you'd only have to worry about finding food. And you would be sorely mistaken. The maps are randomly generated, so what was a problem for you last time you played might not be such an issue for you now. That said, the things that came easy last time may not be so simple this time. For example, I frequently found myself running out of food on my first few attempts, while things like developing new technology came easy. However later on food was a bit easier to find, but I had trouble finding the stone and gold needed to unlock new recipes. THEN once I'd finally found a balance, I made the foolhearty mistake of taking too long to light another torch at night. This game is extremely difficult and while normally a frustrating mechanic such as having to start over everytime you die would put me off, I found myself going, "Well, that sucked. But I wonder what's in store for me next time?" If you're like me and love a good adventure, even if it tests your patience a bit, check this title out. You won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Second Edit: 26 January 2015(NOTE: This review is aimed at new players)So I thought I'd elaborate a little on the context of this game to make this a more useful review like others have made.First of all, this game is HARD.Like. REALLY ♥♥♥♥ING HARD.If you're a newbie at this game, you are going to die ALOT.But that's not a bad thing.If there is one thing this game does right its create an atmosphere thats both immersive & chilling.It is not only a wonderful survival game but an absolutely brilliant adventure game aswell (Once you manage to get to grips with how hard the game can be that is. And you stop dieing as much)By the way, do you think i'm exaggerating with that "You're going to die ALOT" remark?Trust me, I'm not. Though I really wish I was.I'll start you off properly by describing the basic mechanics of the game at the start.First of all, this game is survival based-so you are gonna have a few things to watch out for when you start up a new game. Health, Hunger & Sanity.These are you three basic survival bars which you have to maintain.Hunger being quenched with food items (raw or cooked), and health being quenched also by food, but only certain foods. This means that some foods will give you much less health than others (That is that a majority of the food you come across like carrots, berries and meat will not heal much)Health will  regen slowly over time if you cannot afford to waste limited food resources on it though.And then there's sanity...oh boy.Sanity is the bar that will quite literally wreck your own sanity in real life if you fail to maintain it.It can be regained when lost by picking flowers and you can make a hat from the petals you recieve from those flowers which will majorly slow down the rate at which you loose sanity for a few in-game days. If your sanity get's too low though, shadow mosters will start to physically hurt you.I will describe enemies a little later in this review. But first, crafting!(NOTE: I may re-edit this review another day to describe the crafting in full detail)Crafting is the most important mechanic in this game and can be a littl complicated for begginers to understand in the beggining.For most newbies I would suggest the dont starve wiki to get to grips with the different section of the crafting menu, as describing it here would take me all day.So onto that description of the enemies! Enemies come in all shapes and sizes in Don't starve, and they all spawn in the moment you start.It is your job to avoid them until you are ready to take them down...which takes a while.My suggestion is the same as most would suggest, if you're going to attack anything in the first 10 or so days...make it spiders or singled out pigmen.If your sanity gets to low you will not an immense increase in the amount of shadowy creatures lurking about. These creatures will actually be able to hurt you if your sanity gets low enough.I won't go into too much more detail about the enemies as you probably get the point, most are harder to defeat than some.Now we get to seasons...When you start a new world you can pick to either start in winter or summer. (FYI. Winter sucks)After you get through summer you get to autumn, then winter & then it goes back around to spring and then the cycle repears itself, like real life (not that this game mimics real life cause jesus that would be terrifying)All in all this game is a terrifying but interesting dark survival experience that never fails to get my blood pumping and my brain on overdrive.If you are looking for a survival game that isnt a zombie filled gorefest and actually has some genuinly spooky chill-inducing atmosphere and tight survival gameplay, then this may just be the game for you.An absolute 10/10..............................................................................................................................................First Edit: 29 June 2014I absolutely love this game.Survival mixed with dark/horror themes, your sanity will drain slowly overtime as you encounter strange beasts and dark pits.Not to mention the countless amount of nights spent in fear of literally EVERYTHING.10/10

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												To all those who say there is no story, you obviously have not played enough. Inside the game there is an "adventure mode" which is basically story mode(and very challenging).Crafting is a primary part of the game. It starts very simply — you'll pick up items in the landscape to construct simple tools, necessary to break down more raw materials. The system expands all the way from grass and twigs up to scientific machinery, complex farms and magical devices. The tech tree has enormous depth and room for experimentation, all dependent on your priorities.I recommended this game to anyone who wants to have great time for a couple of hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												IT'S NOT MINECRAFTThe name of the game is really deceiving as starving is one of many ways to die in this game. I'd like to point out here I was expecting something like old Horde game - you stay in a camp, build your defences during the day, defend at night and reap your rewards.It was not the case as instead the developers gave me a game about survival and exploration. I have to say that second "X" part is really crucial for the game, as in early stages you will starve or freak out if you don't collect a lot of food, branches, some little stones that help you start a campfire. This game makes you watch out not only for your hit points but hunger level and serenity as well. Strange things happen if you become insane.Gameplay also brings you back to point'n'click adventure games where you had to find out what can be combined with what. Here it's similiar, it's trial and error with a bit of punishment, but keep in mind: this game is not an extreme hardcore self-destructive masterpiece. The learning curve isn't any steep. It's just a pleasure.As the days go by you learn new things, which gives you a lot of satisfaction. Surviving more and more days also gives you that feeling of progress, because there are new characters to unlock (with different abilities and stats).The downside to this game is that it's kinda cryptic at times and thanks to random generators you can either be in a very good starting position or a very bad one, but usually it doesn't go as far as spawning you next to a lvl 9001 mob which one-hits you.I can recommend this game. I'm not exactly a fan of survive, craft and explore games, but it still gave me some nice memories and I will certainly play it again.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Is this game worth £11 you may ask? Silly question, of course! Inclusing the DLC too, this game is a bundle of amazingness. Don't starve is , if not, on it's way to becoming the best gaming experience around. The fact you get dropped into a completely random world full of so many things that can kill you is so much fun. Of course the main objective is to not starve, but there are so many other obstacles to overcome, and so many ways to do just that. Don't starve is an amazing game that has taken up around 100 hours of my time, and soon to be much, much more. It will soon be multiplayer, so being able to experience all the dangers, problems and sucesses but with some company is something to look forward to.If you do not have patience, then this game probably isn't the best idea. You start off with mainly grass and wood, but as the game flows on, you can be speeding around with a cane, a top hat and some turkey dinner! What could be better? This game just offers such a thrill. The fact it also has great replayability, with other characters and that you can edit your worlds however you like, making it more difficult or easy, or even install some mods made by the fabulous people in the Steam Don't Starve workshop!Overall, if you have some spare time, a bit of money and are looking for a good, fun game, then I definately recommend this one.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This game is plenty of fun delivered in a highly stylised fashion. There's more depth than you first expect; the game can be somewhat difficult and unforgiving at times, but it's always enjoyable.The only thing I'd recommend is to take it slow; don't rush in expecting to kill everything in sight and survive simply by stabbing and punching stuff. You need to build yourself up first before you can take on the big game.On top of that, the game has a good modding community; everything from new items, to tweaks to game mechanics to make things far easier or much harder, new fan-made characters and even total conversions (the base game comes with an official surivival horror themed TC).Overall, Don't Starve is well worth the money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												My review is based on all expansions, not really vanilla. I was attracted to this game due to its art style and cute little Chester. Little did I know this artsy survival game had more to offer than most survival games I've played. Unless you have ROG you're missing out on a lot of content. Don't Starve is far from forgiving, at times you might feel the developers had an evil laugh when coming up with ways to kill us helpless survivors. Don't Starve ROG feels like vanilla to me now, playing Don't Starve itself is not enough to give the game its justice, in my opinion. Don't Starve has a lot of depth, if you're more than just a casual there are so many different things to do on this game besides survive year one. (If you can make it past summer) I do wish, however, Klei put more effort into end game (other than caves OFC) I also feel SW is lacking as an expansion but all in all the price for this game in general feels awfully low for something so wonderful, I would've paid a lot more. If you don't like surviving on your own make sure you give DST a try, the community is great, I prefer Don't Starve over Don't Starve Together but that's just my cup of tea. PS, too the noobs, if you're sceptic due to one death causing your world to be erased, there are items you can craft or things you can find in order to have several lives, not only that, but also mods. The mod community for this game is HUGE, if you ever find yourself bored or feel like you need the game to be a little easier, you could try using mods. Some mods completely change Don't Starve, some make the game easier by adding items and characters, or tweaking things, other mods make the game harder. Don't Starve is a great game and the developers are fantastic and helpful.

												I wasn't too sure about this game when I first saw it.  Then I saw the pocket edition for my phone and decided that I would give it a try. content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												First let's just start with I've put around 10hours into this game and there is still so much I don't know and have not even touched. The best part of this game is not knowing anything about it. Running up to an animal and poking it only to have it two shot you. While you might think like a typical surival game you'll eventually get a cozy farm and endless meat and resources... Suriving is only half the battle. If you want to advance the story and actually get everything out of the game you'll need advanced items, food enough to last you a while away from base and luck in finding what you're looking for. This game has so many layers and so many ways you can play it!There is so much replay value to this game as it is rogue like and your world will be destroyed if you die and your file deleted. While there are one or two methods of gaining... basically an extra life... they're far and few between so just be prepared for lots of deaths at first. You unlock new characters as you progress and survive more and more days so each time you get different buffs ande debuffs making each experience unique and with its own challanges. Overall and amazing game with a ton of depth that is so much more than your average survival game.A huge thing is multiplayer coming out for this game. It says Summer 2015 ALPHA will be released called "Don't Starve Together." This is a major enhancement to the game. Buy it now! The devs have stated once multiplayer is fully released the price of the game will go up to $19.99 from $14.99. So grab a copy and buy one for a friend in preparation!Most importantly, don't starve!Edit 3/23/15: I'd like to add that I reccently added Reign of Giants and oh wow. You should play don't starve to death until you get bored then add the RoG dlc to it. It's a whole new game. The difficulty is much higher since you now have to deal with the rain in Spring and the heat in Summer. It feels like they've added such a huge element to the game. It honestly makes the original base game feel like it was in Early Acess or something. I won't spoil it but there new mobs, tons of new items, new playable characters and just so many new ways to die and ways to avoid dying. Get it!

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												This game. Gameplay: Don't Stave is a survival game which is a genre that has recently been more prominent in games recently due to the success of some game where you punch rocks and ride pigs? anyway Don't Starve in my opinion stands out among the best survival game I have ever played and thats primarily down to the gameplay as its incredibly fun to explore this tim burton style world and survive its dangers. You have a variety of different characters to unlock that each have their own pros and cons and its that diversity which makes playing Don't Starve different everytime you play.. well that and the world is randomly generated everytime you start a new game! so who knows what you will bump into I am still finding new enemies and items to craft and this is coming from a guy who is 20+ hours into the game. Essentially the gameplay consists of gathering wood, flint, stone and food (which is pretty obvious.. I mean the game is called Don't Starve). There are so many items to craft to improve your camp or camps in the massive world you are dropped into and you get a lot of joy from planning out exactly what you are going to collect and make each time you play but that said the game can be a bit overwhelming for new players as you have to think for yourself rather than the game holding your hand which in my opinion works to the games advantage as it adds a sense of accomplishment when you make something to help you survive and if the game told you how to do most things that feeling would not exist and the game wouldn't be anyway near as entertaining. The gameplay is fun and addicting and also stressful at times but not in a bad way as its not the games fault its your fault for forgetting to make a valid step to survive in this beautiful but dangerous world.Story: The story doesn't seem to be the main focus of this game but there is a story hidden in there behind each character you unlock as they are all wacky and have a dark sort of wit to them which I love. The basic premise of this game is that you are dropped into a world by the main villian Maxwell and you have to survive and escape (Or just survive for as long as you can for the lols). There are subtle hints dropped by the characters at points in the game about each characters back story which is very nice.Graphics: This is a beautiful game... its no Skyrim graphical wise but thats not the point this game focuses on art style rather than realism and it works to its advantage as all the characters look like they were taken from concept art by Tim Burton and they are all unique and just as visually interesting as the world of Don't Starve. This is Art. Overall Verdict: Don't Starve is a great game and I look forward to playing it for years to come and I am also looking very forward to the new game mode "Don't Starve Together" which is introducing co-op to the game and I am very interesting in that. Note: People that hate survival games should at least give this one a chance as this is what got me into the survival genre.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2012
												Wonderful. Simple. Brilliant. Entertaining. Don't Starve is a terrifically stylish survivaly sim with a wicked since of humor and mechanics that even the lowly exclusive FarmVille player can adapt to and understand. It's marvelously robust and the game is pulling a Minecraft by being in a very functional beta with updates a plenty coming down to pipe. Get it; I promise you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												I really like the game. It's easy to just start playing, you can use the mouse for everything (particularly crucial for me with repetitive strain injury so I can't do much typing). If you dip into it without preparation (reading forums and the wiki) it's pretty brutal. Permanent death, and frequent! But that just makes it very addictive. I've survived 130 days and can keep my character fed but I'm still being killed by the later hound attacks. There's so much in the game. I like the insanely demanding resource-management against the clock aspect of it. I'm constantly planning and refining new strategies and trying to be more efficient. Inventory-management with so many resources and relatively little space (15 slots main inventory soon fills up. Even with a backpack and Chester I'm still running out of room for everything) is a constant pressure. There's always a hundred different ways to go with each problem. For example, with hound attacks, I've tried toughing it out in melee (works if not too many hounds), hiding under the berry bush hat and hoping the hounds get distracted and killed, and running like a mad thing, hoping they start attacking other monsters on the way. Those are just the most obvious strategies. I could use darts against them (hopefully not taking too much damage if I take some hounds down at range) or build tooth traps with the hounds' teeth they keep dropping when killed, or find a way to get my character resurrected when the hounds kill me (there are at least three ways to resurrect I can think of offhand). And the monsters and their interactions can be so amusing. When I find a beefalo herd, I sometimes take time off from the relentless grind of survival just to watch the baby beefalo playing or sleeping. It still cracks me up.

												My favorite genre of games are survival games and Don't Starve is the survival game that I played a great deal of time.There is always something interesting to do and a new challenge to overcome.  I am a fan of Don't Starve because of the easy to pick up game play and the surprising depth to the game's mechanics.The Tim Burton'esqu hand drawn style graphics are not really the sort of thing that would attract me. content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The graphics are unique and fascinating, personally I love them. Some people even fear the game a bit because the graphics are unsettling to them which I personally just think would only add to the experience of being in a new, hostile world.There are tons of mods for the game if you'd ever get bored of it, a large variety of characters and hours of playtime.The game at first seems real frustrating but in a way that you'd want to give it another shot and avoid what killed you.Also the amount of pets and styles of pets are pretty fun. I personally love Chester most, a treasure chest looking dog creature that follows you around and lets you store things in his mouth.Whenever you seem that the world has dried out and you are sure to die unless you find something that will rejuvinate everyting, it is time to head into the caves. But you risk your life to the new enemies that await you there.It's not ONLY survival as far as you can go, there is for example the Adventure Mode.The different mechanics to the characters and different stats for them make it seem like you're playing another game since you'll have to play the game a completely different way if you're to gain an advantage, so when you've unlocked everything you still might not know what character it is you want to use. None is better than the rest.If you are looking for a realistic game, then this is probably not for you.If you're looking for a game to spend quite a lot of time in and see new types of enemies and like games that look pretty (Perhaps such as Sworcery and Bastion) then this is something you should give a shot.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2013
												Don't starve is 2d survival game with a gorgeous art style that looks like Tim Burton movies have turned into cartoons. There is a sandbox mode, where you try to survive as long as you can, as well as an adventure mode with a minimal story. There is also a wide variety of crafting (as well as cooking) which is neatly organized into different tiers.While the game's purpose is quite simple -not to starve- you get no handholding whatsoever. Your character is stranded in an unknown world, where you need to figure out what to do in order to survive. This can result in several deaths initially, as well as loads of hilarious situations which inevitably occur when you run around poking things. Don't starve is mostly unforgiving to your mistakes -which can end in permanent death- but rewards you with unlocking several characters with unique abilities, in order to spice up your gameplay. There is an option to tweak several world aspects as well, if you are looking for a more casual sandbox experience. I should also mention there are constant updates and a workshop community for this game.Definitely recommend it, if all the above are your cup of tea :)

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												One of the most difficult games I've ever played, yet I keep coming back for more. It'd be easy to stop playing out of frustration, the game doesn't teach you anything and you learn simply by doing. With every death means starting over from scratch, the permadeath is both punishing and extremely rewarding to see how far you will get and how you must adjust your strategy in order to survive. The odds are stacked against you, but it never feels unfair. There is always something you could have done better or a different route you could have taken that may have lead to you living longer. Believe it or not you can even beat this game, or so I've heard.Nothing is more satisfying than figuring out a new mechanic while you are playing simply from experimentation, this game is so finely tuned and balanced that it must've been a nightmare for the devs to make. The combat is excellent yet simple and easy to understand, it is really all you could ask for in a Survival Crafting type game. And to make things even better the Multiplayer version of the game is even more fun, although not yet as feature complete as the singleplayer variant.The graphics are simply beautiful and extremely charming, nothing is more adorable than a sleeping homeless spider or a recently shaved beefalo. Add in unlockable characters, an excellent and tweakable world gen, and a plethora of mods on steam and you have a game that is well worth replaying.

content:

												Such a unique game, I've been playing this since the early access days and it was amazing to see how it evolved, this is the way all Early Access should be managed. The game was always highly playable but evolved into a completely different beast as it neared release, constantly adding, improving and refining content so that each update made the game feel fresh.There's nothing else on the market quite like it, it's not just the tone and aesthetic that differentiate this from other survival games. content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This game is plenty of fun delivered in a highly stylised fashion. There's more depth than you first expect; the game can be somewhat difficult and unforgiving at times, but it's always enjoyable.The only thing I'd recommend is to take it slow; don't rush in expecting to kill everything in sight and survive simply by stabbing and punching stuff. You need to build yourself up first before you can take on the big game.On top of that, the game has a good modding community; everything from new items, to tweaks to game mechanics to make things far easier or much harder, new fan-made characters and even total conversions (the base game comes with an official surivival horror themed TC).Overall, Don't Starve is well worth the money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Review of Don't Starve : Survival games are somewhat my thing, even though i am not good at them, i manage and enjoy playing them!Most survival games are repetitive, like the same world/maps...etc, But not Don't Starve, it is a pandora's box, each gameplay is not the same!The survival in this game is based off 3 thingI) Hunger : it is obvious that a survival game without a hunger meter is no survival game, in this game, there are two ways to get food :1\Hunting2\ planting II) Health : every game has this so there's really no point in explaining!III) Sanity : This is what made the game challenging, you have to keep yourself sane, that is by many ways, but the only one i've discovered is gathering flowers!So let's recap the whole thing : + Single player ( there's a multiplayer version too will be free when you get the game at this time )+ Workshop ( mods )+ Art Style (so you do not have to worry about needing a killing machine PC to play this game)+ Actual working DLC ( Adds a few monters and stuff, so it's worth it to improve the gameplay, but i strongly suggest you get the DLC when you get truly bored from the game )+ Replayable ( since each gameplay is not the same )+ Not a slight bug in sight= Fair XP system+ Many vanilla Characters that differ in skills!So that's a 9/10 i suggest you get it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												My review is based on all expansions, not really vanilla. I was attracted to this game due to its art style and cute little Chester. Little did I know this artsy survival game had more to offer than most survival games I've played. Unless you have ROG you're missing out on a lot of content. Don't Starve is far from forgiving, at times you might feel the developers had an evil laugh when coming up with ways to kill us helpless survivors. Don't Starve ROG feels like vanilla to me now, playing Don't Starve itself is not enough to give the game its justice, in my opinion. Don't Starve has a lot of depth, if you're more than just a casual there are so many different things to do on this game besides survive year one. (If you can make it past summer) I do wish, however, Klei put more effort into end game (other than caves OFC) I also feel SW is lacking as an expansion but all in all the price for this game in general feels awfully low for something so wonderful, I would've paid a lot more. If you don't like surviving on your own make sure you give DST a try, the community is great, I prefer Don't Starve over Don't Starve Together but that's just my cup of tea. PS, too the noobs, if you're sceptic due to one death causing your world to be erased, there are items you can craft or things you can find in order to have several lives, not only that, but also mods. The mod community for this game is HUGE, if you ever find yourself bored or feel like you need the game to be a little easier, you could try using mods. Some mods completely change Don't Starve, some make the game easier by adding items and characters, or tweaking things, other mods make the game harder. Don't Starve is a great game and the developers are fantastic and helpful.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Totally got immersed with the world of Don't Starve the moment I started playing it.Survived for 36 days so far without dying and boy oh boy this game is so much fun and at the same time friggin hard. Went exploring around, met some penguins who tried murder me. Then came winter! Apparently, I build my base next to a walrus camp without knowing and that blob sent his dogs        and was blowing darts at me with 100% accuracy. Killed his dogs and chased him and it took forever to kill him since        he was running away.            Survived two more days after that then ffs a giant abominable cyclops with horns destroyed my base! My point is everything in this game hates you and tries to kill you (If you try to hurt or kill them) Either you get killed by living tree monsters, bees, warthog looking animals, penguins, spiders or you die if you starve. Oh and the Tim Burton visual style for this game suits it very well.Overall, 10/10 for this game and is a must have for those who like Survival games genres.

												Single handly one of the best games I have played in a long time. I love how you are thrown into the world and told nothing about how to get by. I am not the type of gamer who wants to sit through an introduction on how the game is played, or the 20 minutes of intro scenes. This game takes all of that away and leaves you will really unique game play where you have to constantly keep up with your hunger, sanity, and health. 												Love this game think I am going to be playing this for a while.  I have a love/hate relationship with this game. Permadeath with make you punch something after losing your 6 hour + game to a stupid mistake. The game gets better with additional playthroughs and you will see very different worlds each time.  The game has changed a lot since launch and I think klie is making even more content. content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I strongly recommend this game.  Reminds me of Minecraft's first few minutes/hours where you're scraping to stay alive, but this is harder, and more rewarding, minus the building for the most part.  The art style is great, very atmospheric and fun to watch.  Though no in-game instruction is given, the difficulty of picking up on how things work isn't bad, after a couple deaths, you'll know how to progress through the first few days.  That's my one gripe, dying starts you over, with no save game, it automatically deletes it for you.  This lends urgency to your quest to survive, which I like, but the first 3 days or so take half an hour, and there's not much variation in during that time, so it starts to feel a little repetitive.  But after that, there's tons of cool stuff, so it's a minor annoyance.  Also, to be fair, I wouldn't have to play those first three days so many times if I'd just follow the direction, "Don't Starve"

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Don't Starve is a top down 2D survival game! As the player you are dropped into the middle of a wilderness as Wilson (you unlock more characters as you play and survive for longer) and must survive by gathering resources, crafting and fighting monsters as well as your sanity.The art style is incredibly unique and I'm very fond of the gothic look and feel it has. The gameplay is very easy to gain an understanding of, you simply point and click to pick up resources and click to interact with the world. But the difficulty comes when as the days progress and you come face to face with more challenging environments and creatures that don't like what you do.Thing is, in Don't Starve, when you manage to kill certain creatures or you manage to survive past a certain amount of time, you feel like you've really accomplished something. For example, by killing Beefalo, which are incredibly tough very early on you will get great resources for future use which can help you go on for much much longer!This game will constantly frustrate you at the beginning, but learning the game is massively rewarding!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I wasn't too sure about this game when I first saw it.  Then I saw the pocket edition for my phone and decided that I would give it a try.   It took all of 5 minutes for me to realize that I HAD to have this on my PC.  I bought the bundle of the original game,  Reign of Giants, and Shipwrecked. I cannot put this game away.   I think it's totally possible that this game got its title not because of the starvation that can happen in the game but the starvation that can happen to you in the real world when you start playing this game!  I love the exploration that this game puts you through.   I have resisted the urge to watch videos or get tips online because the "not knowing what's going to happen next" aspect really adds to the experience.   Please do yourself a favor and buy this game.   It's well worth the price for the intense HOURS of fun,  stress, frustration, and obsession that you will experience while playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												For such a simple objective--not starving (or dying by creature, cold, heat, darkness, or other means)--this game is extremely rich and complex.  It has two modes; a sandbox survival mode in which your goal is simply to explore and become self-sustaining, and an adventure mode in which your goal is to overcome harsh environments to complete a machine to move to the next world.  You can play either in the spirit of discovering how to construct, create, and build everything yourself or consult and external reference for help, but either way, you'll be presented with a challenge that will keep you occupied and wanting to go a little further for weeks.  I highly recommend it!

The style and art of the game is really cool it makes the game dark and a bit spooky. Sometimes you can get a really annoyed with this game, especially when a pack of hound comes or when you die, but there is something that always keeps dragging you back. I would recomend this game to most people but you have to put in some time to the game to learn to survive in this world. It is also a great game to play while whatcing a movie. And remember to eat anything you can find so you Don't Starve.

												You're dropped into a world with no tutorial, no narration, no guidebook.  Simply click on things, find out what they do, combine them with other things, and LEARN.  This game is brilliant in its simplicity and depth.  With each death, you learn a little bit more about how to survive for longer.  My only complaint is that once you figure out how to survive, the game can stagnate and become rather dull.  Sure, you can make up your own endgame goals, but I wish there was better endgame content.

												I absolutely love this game. You get thrown into the world with absolutely no real tutorials, just the challenge to try to not starve to death, or die from insanity. A tutorial is honeslty not needed though. You can quickly learn the basics through trial and error, exploring new combinations of actions. The ui layout is simple, you have various characters to choose from and even a short minimod available if you choose, which is awesome even for how short it is. I originally saw this on a game stream a friend was watching and had to play it. I am not sure if this still works, but I was able to take my game key and register it within a chrome app so I can even play quick games in my chrome browser at no extra cost. Amazing replay value.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This is basically the premier "survival game", and barring a few classic roguelikes it is also the premier randomly generated game. It owes these high honors to its extremely long development and constant updates, bugfoxes, and balance patches. It's important for a randomly generated game to have a significant amount of content in order to keep replays fresh and exciting; I'm sure it was for this reason that the developers did not stop when the game was merely "adequate". My only complaint is the occasionally inaccurate diablo-style controls that occasionally force the player to learn some strange workarounds. In conclusion if you're not Not Starving yet why aren't you Not Starving?

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
Product received for free
												Gather resources, build weapons, cook food, kill mobs ... sounds like Minecraft eh?That's where the similarities end. This game can be brutal as everything in this game will kill you ... I mean everything!!!Bees ... kill you!Spiders ... kill you!Hounds ... kill you!Horny Beefalo ... kill you!Insanity ... kills you!Hunger ... kills you!Darkness ... kills you!Even winter ... yep, you guessed it, winter kills you as well!If you like survival games and the Tim Burton style graphics, you'll love this game! However, you may find the game challenging and a little frustrating at first until you start to find your way. Don't let this put you off because as soon as you find your way you will immediately find yourself addicted and telling yourself "just one more day then i'll switch off I promise" only to find yourself playing through at least another 10 days ... well, if you survive that long.My tips for getting started:- Explore anywhere and everywhere but find a good base within 5 days if possible ... pigmen are your friend and so are Beefalo (just not when horny!) so pick somewhere nearby- Gather resources as quick as you can and when you think you have enough, collect more ... you'll NEVER have enough!!!- Always make sure you have the ability to make fire, and- Get a weapon ... you never know when the first attack is coming.Remember folks, winter is coming (as well as a lot of angry mobs) so be prepared ... and whatever you do, Don't Starve!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I'm a big minecraft fan, especially playing survival game types. Unfortunately, I have a big issue with minecraft and survival games - it's too damn easy! It's too easy to make impervious shelters, stockpile food, and there arent any mobs that are dangerous if you're cautious and attentative. It's really hard to make the game difficult while still playable, so I've been looking desperately for other options.Don't Starve addresses many of the issues I mentioned above - shelter is hard to build (and never impervious/safe), food can't be easilt stockpiled (it spoils!! Woo!), and enemies can be VERY deadly, even when you are prepared. The seasons are also great in that they impact food availability and hot/cold can do you physical harm. So many great mechanics!Only downside is the game is currently only single player, but they are currently working on Don't Starve Together, which I'm super excited for.In short, if you like survival games but want a more challenging environment, check this game out.

												This game is incredible its just like your basic Sandboxish game with the build and stuff but it also has a legimate adventure mode once you make the diving rod and find maxwells portal anywayDont starve has many aspects so you will die eventually (unless you have a crap ton of farms to last you forever)Plus even if you do die you get xp points so you can get a new characterDont starve offers a very simple way to install mods like all steam stuff anyway~And Dont starve never gets old because if you die you still havn't found everything in the game yet.Another mechanic there is in dont starve is the Sanity system and the being afraid of the dark.During night or doing other stuff such as picking evil flowers can reduce your sanity and the lower it getsthe more Ghosts you see that want to kill you,At night if you dont have any light around you,then you'll just die cuz of monsters lurking in the darkEdit: The dlc "Reign of giants" is a great addition for hardcore players who tend to find dont starve too easy and are looking for a better challenge,one thing we would all like to see tho is Multiplayer in either a mod form or just added to the game.Anyway dont starve is a brilliant game and this is the longest review i've written.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												At first I had thought Don't Starve would be easy, but I soon found out I was way wrong when a tree suddenly turned into a giant monster and murdered me on Day 17. I honestly was not expecting that. That bad experience was not in vain, though. Now I know in my future lives not to chop trees at dawn (seriously, don't). This is a good example of how you must learn from your experiences in order to do well in this game. The only way to succeed is by trial and error, and although it can be extremely frustrating when you lose everything, that is kind of what makes the game fun; knowing such a fate is possible puts you on edge. Also, the mod support is amazing. Getting new mods is literally 3 clicks away, and you can then easily enable/disable them from a convenient menu at the main screen. This is truely a great survival game so buy it if you're in to that kind of stuff, and good luck.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												There is so much to do. There is too much to do. Not enough time. I'm going to waste my life on this game. Maximum I've lasted is 30 days. Either winter or summer, I have not been able to survive. Summer burns everything in its path. Winter is kinda ok, you just need a thermal stone and rabbit earmuffs or beefalo coats.I love the way the map is randomized every time. That way I don't mind beginning anew each time.The game is incredibly difficult. I wonder how many people have actually beaten adventure mode.Frogs and spiders don't attack each other. Or so I found. Thumb rule is to expose an attacking enemy (spiders, bats, frogs) to a non-attacking enemy (beefalo, bees, pigs) while you run around and collect their drops.Cons - no tutorial. That sort of undermines the value of unique items. We store them but we never get around to realizing what they are meant to do. Unless you build those prehestihilitator things.- pixelated graphics at close-up. Maybe it's just the settings. But I can't make out if it reads 12 stones needed or 2.- at default settings, not all characters are present on every map. Not that I've ever explored the whole map. But sometimes, some resources are really scarce. Buy the game. Support the developers. And remember, it's not just Don't Starve. It's Don't Get Hit, Don't Stay in Dark, Don't Eat Mushrooms, Don't nay NEVER Attack Creatures in Groups, Don't Stand Idle, Don't Stop Collecting Twigs, Grass and Rocks, Don't er Do Plant Trees.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is one of the best games i have ever played that is a survival game. The main protagonist is a mad scientist called Wilson who gets sucked into a world, where he (you) have to survive by killing animals for their fur to make clothes for the winter and meat for not starving and pick, garden vegetables for not starving too... and you can make weapons, staffs (magical things), traps, armor and other really cool stuff to survive...The map in this game is random however you chose between small, medium and HIGH (size for the map) but it's nature. A lot of trees, water, flowers, fields and swamps. But be aware you are not alone... there are monsters and wild animals in this game that might not be so friendly as they look like... and you have to build a fire before night comes, because if you don't... shadow monsters will kill you in the darkness without you seeing it coming...And actually you don't always have to play as the main character you can play as other characters once you unlocked them... and you can download other characters at the workshop... but the original characters for this game always have names that starts at the letter "w" except the last character in the list...It's an amazing game with amazing graphics (cartoon graphics) ,amazing music, amazing story, amazing experience, amazing concept and amazing everything!!! :) 10/10 ...But i recommend you buying this game for ps4 (if you have one) because it has a lot of better control for the gamepad then.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												I love this game!  This is a survival game in every essense of the word. In a world where you can die at one simple mistake, it really embodies a true survival experience. The amount of sheer content is enough to pick up this game alone. With randomly generated worlds, many characters that change the way you play, a wide assortment of resources that i'm sure i haven't found all of yet, a great art design, a living, breathing world everytime you boot up a map, caves, ruins, a huge and complex crafting assortment, a story mode, multiplayer being put in after early access of DST, customizable worlds, and one of the best modding communities, this game has an imense amount of lastability and will age extremely well.      The soundtrack is interesting but grows old. After a few hours I started listening to my own music. This is what I call a "wiki game" meaning you will have to live on the wiki if you want to have a clue on what to do. The biggest downfall of this game is the fact that to utilize most of the content, you have to be good, which goes back to the wiki.      Once you've become a grade A survivor, you will find yourself losing countless afternoons on building up your camp, testing new mods and so on. It is an amazing survival games and one of the best indie titles to come out of the past few years. You owe it to yourself not to overlook this masterpiece 10/10       Just look out for penguins......I HAD IT THAT TIME YOU SCUM!!!! AAAAGGGGGGHHHHHH!!!!!!!! Just one more try.....

												When I first came across Don't Starve I assumed it was just another Minecraft clone. After playing for a while, I soon discovered how wrong I was.The game itself, in my opinion, is far superior to Minecraft. It's addicting, quirky, creative, witty and overall lovable. You'll find yourself clinging to dear life as you fight against all odds to stay alive and make it to the end. The gameplay is smooth and easy to get used to, and the art style is magnificent. So much of the game is done perfectly and while the vanilla game is already lovely, the modding community only makes it better. Don't Starve is a great game and I recommend it completely. Oh, and once you get the hang of things you should look into getting the DLC. It's more than worth the price.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is amazing. The style is incredibly cool, the music is great, and the gameplay even better. I cannot find the words to accurately summarise the level of awesome Don't Starve is, it's just absolutely brilliant, in so many ways. As you get no tutorial, no hints (apart from the obvious - don't starve!), it is a game of figuring stuff out at first, and there are so many things to expore, find, and craft! Seeing as you can customise just about everything in your world before you start a game, there are endless possibilities when it comes to difficulty, and not to mention, the dreaded Adventure mode which will make you want to gouge your eyes out with a rusty spoon and throw them at the treeguards while you scream with the fury of a thousand suns. If you like survival, base building, hillarious puns, exploring, crafting, and not having a game tell you exactly what to do at all times - Don't Starve is for you. 10/10 in my book!...Apart from the treeguards. F*** you, treeguards.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												There are plenty of videos out there showing game play, but I think the best recommendation for this game is how much new stuff you still learn about the game on almost every playthrough. At first, the game appears impossible and that everything is out to kill you. While not impossible, most things are out to kill you, and survival is using it to your advantage. Then, as you learn what is important, when is the best time to do things, how to do them, where to go (or not go), and why you should, the game becomes "easier".Make no mistake, on my current playthrough, I am almost to Day 200 and the game is certainly not easier. In fact, some things have gotten more difficult, and death is around every turn. However, this is what makes the game so great.Then, to top it all off, there is Adventure Mode, which is accessed via an object in the Sandbox Mode (where all games start). While Sandbox Mode could be a full game by itself, Adventure Mode is like checking "Hardcore" as you have to take everything you know from Sandbox and use it to make it through all the Chapters (a feat I have yet to accomplish). These Chapters ramp up certain challenges, limit a random resource, etc. Fortunately, this is where the game does let up, as you can repeat Adventure Mode without consquences because you "regain consciousness" upon death in your Sandbox Mode to try again. The best part? The Chapters and levels are regenerated every restart, so you cannot memorize the maps, making it truly an "adventure".tl;dr You want a challenging game that makes you think, and punishes your every mistake? Get this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												After watching trailers and several pictures provided, Don’t Starve’s bettlejuice inspiration, alluring soundtrack, and hand-drawn adorable cast of characters to the wilderness the itself, it begged me to play it. Aside its show and tell features, Don’t Starve truly emphasis the survival genre. Survive however you want to survive: live off the land, wield dark magic, rely on old school hunting tactics, or take your enemies head on to a glorious death. Be prepared for anything and stay well stocked, because if you’re not, the telltale of winter will make survival become much harder. If you find the game too easy, too hard or isn't offering the challenge you want, no problem. There’s plenty of options for you to customize your own world, however you see fit.The asking price is fair or even spot on with its abundance of content and uniqueness makes this survival game truly stand out. Search no further for I utmost recommend this game for those who love survival and looking for uniqueness. The Reign of Giants (RoG) DLC made the game even more content, stronger, dangerous and funnier survival experience.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												This game is a very detailed and complex game that starts out with you waking up and this man pops out of the ground. He tells you to look for some food before nightfall so, you take his advice and get up off the ground in search of flint, food, etc. It seems so simple yet it is so complex! there are many characters in the game that you DO NOT NEED TO BUY! They are all unlocked by survivng and gaining XP. This game is a very addictive game that keeps you coming back! There are also mods like Wulfe, Easter Eggs, and Bigger Stacks (my reccomendations). Check this game out and get the Reign Of Giants DLC, its really cool! So, overall, this game is a fantasy-based game that feels like Minecraft and Terraria but in a 3-D world with more things to craft, much more things to do, and many other fantasy creatures out to get you like Hounds, Tallbirds, Spiders, etc. So, check this game out! And are you good enough to not Starve?

												A 2D Game for All Hardcore Survivors. This game is a strange one. content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Don't Starve is a game about surviving and well, not starving. You search the enviroment collecting necessary items and sometimes even non-necessary items. You encounter monsters. You craft things. It's a game. There are multiple characters. I love it.Pros, things that are good.- Multiple characters with different traits and abilities!- Much replayability!- There are lots of mods to make it even better.- New updates frequently!- GREAT DLC!Neutral, things that can help you and not help you.- Randomly generated world. You could have tons of food, flowers, trees, flint, rocks, other great stuff. And then you could get no food, flowers, trees, flint, rocks, ect.- You play alone. You may have trouble surviving, but you can go at your own pace.Cons, things that are bad.- Day 9 - 11, it's random, gives you hounds to fight.- There are lots of dangerous monsters.Overall, there are more pros than cons, so I reccomend this game to people who like survival games.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2013
												This game is really unique and charming.  I particularly recommend it to fans of survival TV shows as it gives you a survival game experience.In the game, it is a constant struggle to manage your hunger, health and sanity levels.  You are always prioritizing what you need to better your survival situation.  You rarely have time to sit around idle, and are always on the hunt for things you need while fending off occasional attacks from wild hounds or other creatures you come across.Also, with the addition of Steam Workshop, you can easily tailor the game even more to your liking.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												I went into this game thinking it would be something like Minecraft or Terraria.Boy, was I wrong.A survival/crafting game that mixes together crafting, survival, and psychological horror (in a sense), this game was a refreshing change of pace from the world of "straight-forward sandboxes."  The world is alive with all sorts of flora and fauna to gather and hunt, but not all of it will just accept their fate of becoming your next meal.Will you be able to survive the purgatorial landscape as you struggle to live on through the night?  Or will you succumb to the horrors of the night that will turn the hunter into the hunted?Overall, I give this game 5 live-saving fires out of 5

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												At first I had thought Don't Starve would be easy, but I soon found out I was way wrong when a tree suddenly turned into a giant monster and murdered me on Day 17. I honestly was not expecting that. That bad experience was not in vain, though. Now I know in my future lives not to chop trees at dawn (seriously, don't). This is a good example of how you must learn from your experiences in order to do well in this game. The only way to succeed is by trial and error, and although it can be extremely frustrating when you lose everything, that is kind of what makes the game fun; knowing such a fate is possible puts you on edge. Also, the mod support is amazing. Getting new mods is literally 3 clicks away, and you can then easily enable/disable them from a convenient menu at the main screen. This is truely a great survival game so buy it if you're in to that kind of stuff, and good luck.

content:
Posted: April 22
												Don't Starve is one of the best crafted titles in my entire library. Everything works together exceptionally well. The Burtonesque art style is great, the slightly disturbing music continually sets me on edge and the things that go bump in the night make me jump in the day. The game is one of survival. You'll be chopping wood, mining ore, farming....oh wait, this sounds familiar. It sounds like every other survival game. Except it's not. You're going to be crafting some really odd things with odd ingredients. Without spoiling it for you, there's just a lot of weird things that you can and will need to make out of wood, stone, gold, monster meat, etc.  Weapns. Armor. Boomerrangs. Crock pots. Science machines. That's the normal stuff - the weird stuff is just weird. You'll be facing creatures that are cartoonish nightmares. You're going to explore a game world that's quite original and of course, randomly generated with each start.And you're going to die. A lot. In fact, Don't Starve isn't a game. It's a death simulator.You'll die of starvation.You'll die of exposure.You'll die from bees.You'll die from walking trees.You'll die from ostrich-looking things.You'll die from your beefalos in rutting season.You'll die from things that go bump in the night.You'll die because you went insane.You'll die by spiders. You'll die by a dozen other things.And maybe, you might just starve.It's a survival game and there's no saving, so one mistake and you'll be restarting again from scratch. I generally hate that and avoid games that require restarts. Yet I keep playing Don't Starve. It's the favorite game in my library that I truly, completely suck at playing. I'm terrible and yet I have a good time.This is one that no gamer should be without.PS - Note that there are a couple of expansions for this. I never picked them up because they make the game harder and I don't need the help dying.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2013
												Don't starve is 2d survival game with a gorgeous art style that looks like Tim Burton movies have turned into cartoons. There is a sandbox mode, where you try to survive as long as you can, as well as an adventure mode with a minimal story. There is also a wide variety of crafting (as well as cooking) which is neatly organized into different tiers.While the game's purpose is quite simple -not to starve- you get no handholding whatsoever. Your character is stranded in an unknown world, where you need to figure out what to do in order to survive. This can result in several deaths initially, as well as loads of hilarious situations which inevitably occur when you run around poking things. Don't starve is mostly unforgiving to your mistakes -which can end in permanent death- but rewards you with unlocking several characters with unique abilities, in order to spice up your gameplay. There is an option to tweak several world aspects as well, if you are looking for a more casual sandbox experience. I should also mention there are constant updates and a workshop community for this game.Definitely recommend it, if all the above are your cup of tea :)

content:
Posted: January 24
												I bought this game a couple of years ago and since then have notched up close to 1000 hours after probably a break of six months or so, I felt drawn back recently.  For those who don't know, DS comes in essentially four formats - vanilla (Original DS), Reign of Giants - more challenges more environmental hazards, DS Together (Multiplayer) and Shipwrecked.  DS is a quirky and fun survivalist game, the Tim Burton style graphics are part of the significant charm of Don't Starve.  Arriving in a world with nothing, you must forage, build a base camp, hunt, trap, fish and farm... all the time exploring whilst preparing for battle with the bosses and the harsh weather conditions of the next seasons whilst trying to keep the nightmares away.  There are multiple characters to play as, having different strengths and weaknesses and their own unique charm. There are many different ways to play this game, you can be an animal lover, just living off what you can farm, or hunt down the various animals in game for a meatier diet.  You can have a central base or live a more nomadic lifestyle with perhaps smaller satalite bases dotted around the world.  There is an adventure mode and also the ability to decamp and travel to a newly generated world when you get bored of your current one.  Since the launch of DS shipwrecked it is now possible to link a DS Reign of Giants world to a Shipwrecked world, allowing you the ability to world hop back and forth and enjoy two different worlds within one game.The world is extensive, and comes with significant customisation options to allow you to design bespoke worlds to suit your game play, in addition to this the modding community have gone to town with this game, providing all kinds of bolt on mods including additional bosses/beasts and characters for gamers to enjoy.  When I stumbled across this beauty on a Youtube video, I knew immediately that I wanted it.  I died so many times in the first few weeks and I remember the first time I made it to day 21 in DS and the start of Winter, only to spend a pitiful 2 days by the fire with no warm clothing and no means to make it far enough to find the resources to make the clothing... cue another frustrating death.  Fortunately, one of the best parts of this game is that starting over is as engaging as being 100 + days in, the battle against time to prepare for what's to come, the flexibility of world hopping when this world becomes a chore or over run with spider queens or stripped of resources.... The thought that has gone into DS is brilliant, its a game that is gripping, fun and challenging.  Don't be fooled though by its cute quirky graphics... you will die lots, you will laugh, cry, threaten to throw your computer through the window... and you will love it.  It really is a game that will provide endless hours of ammusment. I can highly reccomend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The graphics are unique and fascinating, personally I love them. Some people even fear the game a bit because the graphics are unsettling to them which I personally just think would only add to the experience of being in a new, hostile world.There are tons of mods for the game if you'd ever get bored of it, a large variety of characters and hours of playtime.The game at first seems real frustrating but in a way that you'd want to give it another shot and avoid what killed you.Also the amount of pets and styles of pets are pretty fun. I personally love Chester most, a treasure chest looking dog creature that follows you around and lets you store things in his mouth.Whenever you seem that the world has dried out and you are sure to die unless you find something that will rejuvinate everyting, it is time to head into the caves. But you risk your life to the new enemies that await you there.It's not ONLY survival as far as you can go, there is for example the Adventure Mode.The different mechanics to the characters and different stats for them make it seem like you're playing another game since you'll have to play the game a completely different way if you're to gain an advantage, so when you've unlocked everything you still might not know what character it is you want to use. None is better than the rest.If you are looking for a realistic game, then this is probably not for you.If you're looking for a game to spend quite a lot of time in and see new types of enemies and like games that look pretty (Perhaps such as Sworcery and Bastion) then this is something you should give a shot.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2013
												This game runs fine on my old PC, and that's why I started playing it.  Then, unlike other less demanding games, this game is quite fun to play and can be addictive for awhile.  That's because you are watching yourself slowly going insane, starve to death, or die from loosing health, and it's difficult to deal with the problems right away.  It requires planning, tactics, and right executions to survive against lack of resources (food / rocks), cold weather, and sudden dangers from monsters.The game gets updated quite regularly, and it becomes slightly harder - because of introduction to new element : rainy day, new monster, etc.  If you have one in your inventory, I recommend adding it to your library and start playing it, before it gets too difficult.
