content:
Posted: April 5, 2013
												This game runs fine on my old PC, and that's why I started playing it.  Then, unlike other less demanding games, this game is quite fun to play and can be addictive for awhile.  That's because you are watching yourself slowly going insane, starve to death, or die from loosing health, and it's difficult to deal with the problems right away.  It requires planning, tactics, and right executions to survive against lack of resources (food / rocks), cold weather, and sudden dangers from monsters.The game gets updated quite regularly, and it becomes slightly harder - because of introduction to new element : rainy day, new monster, etc.  If you have one in your inventory, I recommend adding it to your library and start playing it, before it gets too difficult.

												An insidious little game that presents itself to you in an easy to understand and play interface but has astounding depth and replay value. You will die, a lot. And with each death learn, and become better at surviving. And try again. And again. And again. When you have mastered surviving winter, giant monsters will demolish you. When you survive giant monsters, cave dwelling beasts will devour you. When you survive even those, youa re ready for Reign of Giants and Summer witll make you long for winter. And you will never be able to put this game down.Dont get this game. IT will take time away from getting through your backloig. :p

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Don't stave is a very unique game. Not only because of the gameplay, but also because of the artwork.But seriously, i really can't compare this game with any other game i have ever played.It's a survival, sandbox, building, fighting and crafting game basically.You craft your own weapons, your own tools, you can build traps to catch other animals with, you can build your own base (not a house, but a base) and try to survive pretty much.The crafting menu in this game is very organized and readily comprehensible, which is a must, especially if you play other crafting games you sometimes forget how to craft what.You can also unlock and play as other characters who all have different perks, so that's another point for the replayabilty of this game.The seasons in this game also change from spring to summer to autumn to winter (if you survive that long.)There are also different "stages." On the map there are various locations of "worm holes." When you jump into them, they teleport you to another map.I haven't seen that much from this game yet, so i can't go into too much detail, but i like what i have seen so far.I would recommend this game, especially if you like survival and crafting games. It's very unique, both gameplay and artwork-wise and there is a lot to discover. Also because the maps are always randomly generated.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Don't Starve is an addictive game that requires you to not only not starve but live through multiple challenges that constantly threaten your survival. It has wonderful artwork that creates a charming yet creepy atmosphere. It reminds me of Tim Burton's style. I love the size of the world and what you stumble across in your explorations. Artifacts (useful and not), skeletons with helpful equipment and my favorite, the Beefalo. It's great that you can tweak the game to your liking and have different characters to choose from. The characters are imaginative with their own strengths and weaknesses. I recommend this game. It's well worth it and has a lot of replay value.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												This is that sort of game that'll kick you in the groin and then give you a reasurring pat...ONLY TO KICK YOU IN THE GROIN AGAIN.I hate it....Probably one of my top ten games.Don't starve is a survival game with a mixture of 2D and 3D graphics creating a 3D world filled with 2D characters,items and what not. The game will send you into the wildreness without any tips and you'll learn on from there. Don't Starve is a game that offers a lot but does it slowly so there are those who would find the first one or two hours of playing in a new save (world) boring. The most GLORIOUS thing about it is,exactly,the sheer lack of knowledge. From the first five minutes,you'll learn the basic controls on your own,but you will encounter many new things that you will have no idea what they are and the only way to learn would be to interact with them....Experiment,pick 'em up,eat them,burn them,attack them...Of course,do know that you might end up dead and....Yeah,it's that game. It's that glorious perma-death game and it was delivered very nicely.Please,just,PLEASE don't go looking for 620 kink scope try hard guides on how to be PR0 at this game as it'll just remove all the fun fo learning on your own. It is much better if the player is forced to explore and learn on their own,even if it means going through trial and error. The worlds are always randomly generated which give the game a somewhat different flavour every time you play and let's not forget the different characters with different perks which will affect your play style too.Hunt,gather and make your own camp...Then spend the nights trembling in fear next to your campfire hoping those ''things'' don't gather the wits to come near the light of your fire....And then...When all of that is done and when you think that you've survived the worst,winter comes making everything much harder to get to and,once again,changing your tactics and food rationing.Definitely a game worth playing,thouh I can only imagine this having a small Multiplayer mode. Perhaps two to four players surviving together?

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Don't let the adorable Tim Burton-style graphics and cute beefalo fool you. This is a game that wants you to die.Repeatedly.Even if you make the game easier (you can disable some of the more game ending monsters from spawning!) on your poor, weather-beaten and starving soul, you are still going to die.But you'll like it. You'll do it again and again and you may just forget you were supposed to do adventure mode and actually accomplish something other than establishing your base camp.Since purchasing this game during the summer sale, I have been completely in love with Don't Starve. The object is simple; survive. It's just that the whole surviving part isn't that simple and you'll end up killing yourself if the wildlife doesn't do that on your behalf. I guess that's what makes it so addicting. I keep learning from my mistakes and I build better farms. I get myself better armor faster and I've figured out what I failed to do in winter that kept me from surviving the next summer.It's a survival game in which you'll collect items, learn recipes, and kiss your character "good luck" as you embark on a little adventure. Do some farming! Do some exploring! Do some fighting! ...and then run for your life!The music is lovely and fits the mood from each day dawning to a change of scenery (and boss battles with trees from satan). Worth noting with the music character has an instrument that serves as a speaking voice, embodying their personalities as you learn to get along with them as you well, don't starve! Each character is unique and provides pros and cons to their playing style. Personally, I'm a fan of Willow, Wendy, and Wilson. You'll notice that each character has a name starting with the letter W and there is a much larger connection to everyone than at first glance. It's rather neat and I'll admit, I spoiled myself after I reached day thirty and died in a ball of fire.Graphics are dark and cartoony. You'll think Tim Burton or one of your favorite "edgy" and darker cartoons of the 90s that we all had as some brain junk food. It's actually rather cute and can make even the most ugly and terrifying creatures in the game look very disarming until they try to rip your head off and suck out your fluids. For this type of game and the storyline eluded to, it works. It's delightfully creepy yet you're smiling along because it's a twisted little world you're traversing in. Nothing is at all what it seems, but you can't help admire what pretty little things are there.Until they murder you.This isn't a difficult game to learn. Use the mouse and the WSDA keys to move. I tend to use both and click with the mouse to harvest or order a character to act, leaving ample time to react to things such as demonic wolves wielding fire (yes they're in this game and I'm not sure why wolves need sometimes need fire when teeth and claws were perfectly fine, but the game is called Don't Starve, not Easy Super Happy Camp Time).You'll be tempted to sometimes play this game in long marathons. While there's no work-out you'll get from your mouse or keyboard, give your eyes a break. The only sudden flashes you'll find is from in-game lightning, but this can actually be disabled before you start a new world.While you might get a jump from things coming out of the woodworks to kill you and ruin your hard work or you may feel very frustrated when you accidentally set fire to your camp and ruin about a hundred days worth of work, I still find this game to have everything I was looking for after a long time of searching. No rampaging armies. Just me and the elements as my own doom.If you've got a short temper or you dislike doing repetitive things in order to build up a catche and THEN venture forth, this probably isn't something you're going to like. For me, however? I needed this game a long time ago and I'm very ashamed I didn't get it sooner. It's my new favorite game and you'll pry it out of my cold, dead, starving fingers.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2013
												Here is my personal review of Don't StarveGame play: Don't Starve offers an immense spectrum of how to approach surviving.  Players will be able to survive the way they want to survive and discovering what works and what doesn't is part of the fun of Don't Starve.  Use the Don't Starve wiki to a minimum and learn to play the game your way.  Don't Starve can be fun for children and adults.  There is very little room Don't Starve leaves for boredom, really the only downtime I have found is those nights I get caught away from my base, which often turn out to be the scariest.Sound/Music: Not much to say here.  The sound is not annoying or appealing in any significant way.  I often turn the music down or off, as it can drown out the hounds calling.  When tired of the music  I replace with any music that I enjoy listening to at low volume.  The music is fitting and well done, but pretty repetitive after so many hours.Controls: I have now played with both keyboard/mouse and controller, I will have to admit I prefer the controller now.  There are times where I wish I had the mouse again, so there are advantages and disadvantages to both.  In a way that is unique, I usually find myself of the opinion that one method is superior to the other.  The control system shouldn't disappoint a new player or even a veteran player and the control mechanics will not leave much to be desired.Graphics: Being a 2D and stylized game, the artwork must be impressionistic to vitalize the player's cognitive reception.  Don't Starve accomplishes itself graphically with a simple approach that does not get in the way of the game's strengths.  The only part of the graphics that seem odd to me is the ocean or shore lines, but again that doesn't actually affect the game in any negative way.  Value: Currently at $15 Don't Starve is a great value.  The game is fun, appropriate for family, and has good replay value.  Also purchasing now is a good investment for Don't Starve Together which is an update coming soon that adds multi-player.  They plan to increase the price of the game by $5 when that update is live.  Likes/Dislikes:The most distinguishable ingredients of Don't Starve is the survival balance.  The game is not too hard and not too easy, yet if you feel one way or another you can modify the game world how you see fit.  I enjoy the ability to create a base, but not have it so powerful that it breaks the difficulty.  I also love that the game is a wilderness survival game and doesn't offer a house or tower to stand atop to break the threat of enemies on the ground.Little upsets I have had is the worm-holes and how you cannot enter a worm hole while being attacked; I've died like this multiple times now and still have not learned that lesson.  The need to rotate the camera is often aggravating and disorienting, but there are some remedies to that.  Conclusion:A very pronounced title that offers intimidating experiences in wilderness survival.  Don't Starve holds a key to my desire that many survival games do not.  I hope to see more of Don't Starve in the future, especially with Don't Starve Together.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I adore this game. It's a quirky survivalist game, but don't let the adorable artwork confuse you---this is not an easy game. The UI is minimal and the controls are simple, and in the beginning the learning curve isn't too steep. Find food; collect items to make a fire. Stay in the light. Not so hard, right?Until you start exploring, and you find unknown foods, unknown creatures, and unknown items. Will you eat that mushroom? Those berries? Will you touch that giantic bird thing that you've never seen before and it looks like it might be frien----NO, OH NO, DO NOT TOUCH THAT BIRD RUUUUNNNNNNNNNNN....Ahem. This is a clever and wickedly addicting survival game that will keep you on your toes. Even better, it's now multiplayer--though don't think that makes it a whole lot easier... The main game has permanent death, which I actually quite enjoy. There's something so exciting about surviving longer than any other time you've played. If you really wish you can turn that option off, however. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to find out what happens when I use a sleeping dart on that giant tree thing over there.

content:

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												A deliciously brutal game of discovery.  The main game is highly customizeable for those who want to take a pleasant camping trip, but the game offers a real sense of accomplishment for those looking for a challenge.  Every death is a lesson learned, and you'll find yourself saying "I'll just play for a couple more minutes so that I can build this or hunt that."  There are plenty of characters to be earned as well, which helps keep the experience interesting.  This is definitely a game where you must set your own goals and plan ahead; if you are the type of player who wants quests and clearly defined objectives, this is not the game for you.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Already died over 30 times. Wilson never even lived to see another day on the first game.The following characters lived for less than 10 days. As I learned more about the game, I got really hooked up with gathering items so that I can get my character to craft and eventually fighting monsters for the loot. I enjoyed looking for food sources and then cooking crockpot recipes. Figuring out how I should build my base also got me really interested more with other events that may happen in the game. Eventually I got Wilson surviving through the winter and was able to make him live for more than 100 days. Most of my playtime were done in survival mode, now I think I am ready for adventure mode.

content:

												Dont starve is one of those games that every time you play you get a little better at it and in doing so you feel an overall feeling of acheivement not seen in many games (dare i say it,it reminded me of the feeling i had playing dark souls).Very much like the classic games from FROM SOFTWARE this game throws you in at the deep end and you either sink or swim,having said that every time you die when you play next time you know a little bit more to get that little bit further and survive for that little bit longer.I have many a time played this game and yet i seem to keep being surprised by the amount of new things i keep bumping into (especially during a full moon OH THAT WAS CREEPY).I love the games that the developers made before this one (the shank games are fantastic-still remind me of the film machete though) but i think that this game is their crowning glory and will be hard for them to top.The graphics suit this game and just add to the overall experience you have whilst playing.Again this is another game that again shows up the big developers and shows that smaller developers have more more orriginality than they do (money does'nt allways mean that your game is the best and shiny graphice dont allways make good gameplay please take note all you power hungry developers).In closing i love this game and if you want a challenge you should look no further than DONT STARVE.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												A richly animated and darkly humorous wilderness survival game for those who enjoy a bit of madness mixed in with their gameplay. Don't Starve includes a generous array of unlockable characters, each with their own strengths, idiosyncrasies, and caveats. This game is unforgiving, but the challenge proves highly entertaining and provides this game substantial replayability. This game will delight those who enjoy crafting, researching, and hunting, as all three prove to be imperative to survival in this delightfully quirky and dangerously addictive game. I highly recommend this game to all those who might enjoy a survival game with a darkly whimsical twist.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Don't Starve Review ThoughtsDon’t Starve is a game in constant motion, updates and gameplay overhauls are as common as pengulls in the midst of a freezing winter. Because of this Don’t Starve is a game that is impossible to review, but with the recently released Reign of Giants DLC, Don’t Starve has once again stolen significant parts of my free time. With tree guardians, giant geese and devastating half-bear-half-badger base destroying beasts taking place in my everyday thoughts, I figured now is a better time than ever to express my thoughts on this truly unique hardcore survival game.Don’t Starve starts with the player waking up into an unknown world, you are equipped with nothing but the clothes on your back, your goal at first seems to simply be: find something to eat. Though as time progresses, starvation becomes the least of your worries, as you discover the world you find yourself in is filled with mystery and threat beyond your comprehension. Don’t Starve is a game of brutal challenge, the one life you are given keeps you constantly on the edge of your seat, death can come at the most unexpected times and each one becomes more painful than the last. This challenge is not an unwelcome one, the repetition can become mundane, and it may discourage some, but the nature of the one life system is necessary to make the game what it is. Don’t Starve would be a very different experience if things were not the way they are.Don’t Starve is as much about survival as it is about exploration, as I mentioned before, the world is filled with many mysteries and things to discover, the world is quite enriching, and the lore is fascinating, nothing about the game is generic or uninteresting. Every character, enemy and locale is unique and like no other. Whether it’s the bunnymen or koalefant, mechanical chess piece, or boy trapped inside a spider. Don’t Starve is a spark of creative genius. Don’t Starve is a game that has really caught my interest, this is not a review, (Though it seems this has turned out in a way that heavily suggests that it is indeed a review.) so I am not going to tell you that you should buy the game of question. (Though technically this is supposed to be a recommendation, at least according to Steam’s standards.) However, after reading this post, (See how I am careful not to use the term ‘review’.) it should be glaringly obvious that I am enjoying my time with Don’t Starve. However, I am not going to recommend this to you as I decided early on that this is not a review. Actually, I changed my mind, I have rambled long enough on this last paragraph and I don’t care anymore. You should buy Don’t Starve. Done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Imagine. You are a mad scientist, plucked from your lab and dropped in the wilderness with naught but the clothes on your back. And it's not just any normal wilderness, oh no! It's one filled with strange and dangerous creatures! Its up to you to survive, using all the natural resources available to you, as well as your own ingenuity! Just, don't forget to eat. And dont forget to pack a torch either.Don't Starve is an exercize in survival. You need to keep yourself fed to avoid starvation, you need to fight off monsters as you explore your surroundings, and whatever happens, you need to make sure you have a source of light at night. Failure at any of the aforementioned three means you die, and have to start over in an entirely new world! Don't Starve is surprisingly complex and can eat away hours of your time as you try to figure out new items to build, new food recipes to try out (that may or may not be poisonous) and new ways to help you stay alive in a hostile world! If you're an avid lover of indie games with a flair for the strange and the creepy, Don't Starve is at the top of my list for you to buy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Don't Starve is an addictingly entertaining game, worth every penny. It is a survival sandbox game, where the ultimate goal is to... don't starve... and explore the vast wilderness and survive for as long as possible. The game is based on a rogue-like concept, which means that every time you play a game, everything is randomized. In addition, the game offers no tutorials or guides on how to play, which only enhances the aspect of exploration. This is definitely the best element this game has to offer, as there are numerous things to discover, even after 90+ hours of gameplay. As with most rogue-likes, the game can be quite difficult, and death often lurks behind every corner. The game also features permanent death, which means that once you die, you will have to start all over again, although there are ways to cheat death a couple of times. There are a number of different characters to unlock through varius means. They have emphasis on different aspects of gameplay, which can either make the game easier or harder for you. In addition, they have all a unique ability that differentiates themselves from the other characters. The visual aspect of the game is pleasing, and the audio is very enjoyable. It perfectly supplements the cartoonish atmosphere of the game.Additionally, the community is great. There is a plethora of mods and guides available. The modding community is vast and the mods can either make life easier or more difficult for you, depending on your preferences, and veteran Don't Starve players can utilize mods to keep the game alive for a long time. For new players, there are tons of guides to be found, many of which I have used myself. They are a valuable resource when you are in need of tips and tricks. All in all, a great indie survival game, which I would recommendable: 10/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												There are obvious comparisons to be made to other crafting games and evryone loves the Tim Burton-esque art style (as do I). However what I really like about this game is the fanastic use of tension. The music, the lighting, the apparitions that come with insanity. It feels like you are moments from death at any time and it's wonderfully immersive in this sense.There is also a lot to learn, I recommend keeping the wiki open in the background at all times, it saved my life more than I care to mention.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												3rd death on "Don't Starve" but I feel I have learnt valuable lessons.1. Darkness kills you. I don't even know WHAT killed me, so I will say it was a mutated Jigglypuff.2. Do not attack bees with an axe, they dominate you. THEY ARE STINGY DOOM PIES THAT FLY. 3. Even if you have a spear, it will not kill the massive one eyed bird of doom and deathly deathness. It will also destroy your very being and you'll also die harder than the doomy bee death.So yes, buy the game, it is stupidly fun, even when you die. Beautifully created and your character is lovely and sarcastic at times. One day, I will survive long enough to build my own house and survive through the doom. Until then, I will just randomly charge at the unknown and probably die ^.^

												Very charming art style. But don't let that fool you. 												Just now getting around to this, okay Don't Starve is a dark, humorous and challenging game. I can only last a few days before dying by some random monster I've never seen before but it just makes me more determined to last longer than I did before. Things that are neat about the game: Each character is different, the visuals are creeply delicious, the sounds are adorable, the turkeys especially, various monsters, crafting, etc.And you can edit each world to your liking, like how many carrots you want or trees, stuff like that.Also there are some really neat mods.I'd recommend it for any survival game fan who is looking for something different and challenging.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												Engrossing, challenging and accessable. I've spent many hours trying to survive. I even found a gateway to Maxwell, but then I died. I've died hundreds of times. I've survived to 22 days on more than one occasion. I've gone insane from lack of sleep too many times to count -- I finally learned how to make a bedroll and survive longer than a few days. I've fought tree guardians and eyes that grow from the ground. I managed to kill a turkey once and I have killed *tall* birds to get meat and their eggs. I've mind gold and made machines. But in the end, I've always died. Don't starve is well named. It's all about survival in a *very* hostile world. Who would every have thought that dying would be fun?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												As a fan of these type of games (in which you have to work and work to get what you want - ex. Harvest Moon, games like that) , I recommend this game to those with a lot of patience and time, who won't just quit in frustration after the first few plays. If the gameplay doesn't drag you in, then the plot-line will if you follow it. The Tim Burton style gives it a nice, creepy touch that I applaud it for. The mechanics are well-implemented, and the time-management factor is a great touch to it, since you may have to plan out what you're going to do and how long you have to get to a certain area, what's more important to focus on for a day (dedicating a day to rabbit-hunting, chopping wood, tending to a base) and so on and so forth; some survival games don't put this in very well, but this one certainly does. Sometimes it does get a little frustrating, but once you get the hang of it, it gets very fun and addicting; you never know what's ahead until you explore. 10/10, definitely would recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Imagine. You are a mad scientist, plucked from your lab and dropped in the wilderness with naught but the clothes on your back. And it's not just any normal wilderness, oh no! It's one filled with strange and dangerous creatures! Its up to you to survive, using all the natural resources available to you, as well as your own ingenuity! Just, don't forget to eat. And dont forget to pack a torch either.Don't Starve is an exercize in survival. You need to keep yourself fed to avoid starvation, you need to fight off monsters as you explore your surroundings, and whatever happens, you need to make sure you have a source of light at night. Failure at any of the aforementioned three means you die, and have to start over in an entirely new world! Don't Starve is surprisingly complex and can eat away hours of your time as you try to figure out new items to build, new food recipes to try out (that may or may not be poisonous) and new ways to help you stay alive in a hostile world! If you're an avid lover of indie games with a flair for the strange and the creepy, Don't Starve is at the top of my list for you to buy!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												[TL;DR, Never owned the game, but I've played it before. Here's my view on it.]For the few minutes that I played this game when I had it free, it was a plesant expirence.I spawned in a world, in the middle of a desert. There were a few rocks, some bits of tall grass.As I explored some more, I found a forest with some trees and berry bushes.As I was gathering resources though, it became night. I set up a campfire and roasted some berries, keeping myself alive through the darkness.When it became morning, I found a touchstone to set a temporary respawn, and set up shop nearby.Soon I had grinded enough things to create some tools, and was able to quickly mine some rocks to aid my progress to a science machine. After I got it built, I had already created some armor, a few chests, a campfire, some farms and rabbit traps.Then I discovered my new found nemesis: The Hounds. Terrifying pig-dog creatures that attack you around every ten nights, about full moon time as well. I was able to kill the two that attacked, but was wounded horribly.I cooked up some meatballs in the crockpot I had made not too long ago and was able to restore most of my health.My journey ended in the harsh winter, when my crops wouldn't grow, and rabbit were scarce. The Hounds came for me in my weakest state, and I died not once, but twice, after respawning from the touchstone.Sure, I never owned the game from buying it, but I do highly recommend it for the people who like adventure, challange and exploration.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Very cool little survival and crafting game.  Casual in it's gameplay but also challenging and rewarding at the same time.  The graphics are in the stylized in a creepy comic book sort of fashion that serves the theme of the game very well.  The sound design and music are excellent and only enhance the experience rather than distract from it.  Most importantly though, the game is simple to get into and features some very intuitive and streamlined controls.  Whether you're using a mouse and keyboard or a gamepad, players will be able to jump into the game and explore the Don't Starve with relative ease.  The challenge is finding the ingredients and materials necessary to survive while discovering the usefulness of each item and tool that becomes available, all while avoiding the dangerous creatures that come out at night and the lingering darkness they bring with it.    ---  The Good  ---  - Nice graphical style- Great sound design and music- Intuitive gameplay and user friendly control scheme- Made for gamers of all skill levels and backgrounds (casual and diehard gamers alike)- Both Mouse & Keyboard and even Gamepad support!  ---  The Bad  ---  - Nothing really, this game is very good all around!- The only thing that might throw off newcomers is the fact that they  will need to discover what they'll need to do within the game all on their own without very much help.  The game is relatively easy to figure out though and shouldn't cause frustration for even the most casual of gamers and newcomers to gaming.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												One of the hardest game i have ever played, yet one of the best. However, anybody can change game difficulty: add more food or less monsters, and for others who high-seek challenges can be far more harder by adding plenty spiders, pigs, monsterous bosses. That makes just epic game: checkboard robots fight with buffallos when spiders try to kill both of them. More of it, having all kind of supplies trying to kill boss for about 20mins with magic, medieval spikes or even with fellowship pig squad. Characters is well optimised for all kinds of players. Wigfred is just amazing at fights, Maxwell having his own astonishing duplicates of himself, what makes him evil master. Have to mention Woody with his terrible secret, that is just ridiculous!Map has several district areas, what eventually makes you go deepeer in the woods, or even in dungeons against rock skin crabs, mystical and huge bunnies, insane monkeys, or even dragons. Yes, that's right - tremendous DRAGONS!Also, one of the most amazing thing in this game is seasons: i thought winter is hard to stay warm, but when update released summer, it was far more harder to understand how to survive. Although, some of survivers say that this game needs some tutorial, but i think it's better to understand by yourself how to survive, that's what make this game awesome. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												I liked this this game because it was unique in art style. I liked how the survival mechanics worked, like warming yourself up, keeping your sanity up, and food. I also really liked weather and seasons. I don't see that very often in survival games. I liked seasons in Don't Starve because surviving in each season was different and had to be played differently. There's also magical weapons and a cool crafting system.  I only have 2 negative things to say about this game.  There's not really a tutorial. So things are pretty confusing at first. Needless to say, your first games you probably wont live a week The game get's slower paced and repetetive after you start getting good items. Fortunatly, Reign of Giant remedies it to an extent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Don't starve is one of those Indy Games that you like, play fore a while, get addicted to, play a little longer and the put it away for a year or so to start the process again later on.The way this game plays, feels and is being experienced just works for me. the art feels both safe (mainly because it is cartoony) and yet dark too. And for a game in which the dark will kill you and you'll have to create light to stay alive that is great! At night you'll be terrified while feeding your campfire with the last pieces of wood, and during the day you'll be ready for an adventure to gather supplies, food and weaponrry for the next night (and day).I must admit, after playing it for too long it will get boring. mainly because it's still an indy game which just isn't build for great scale and an unlimited supply of options (Except for the all-known Mojang Project, if you get my drift). But, after a while, you can pick it up again an loose yourself again for a couple of weeks (maybe months).For the price I would say it is definately worth it! Great and addictive to certain extend, 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Don't Starve is an amazing game, not only because of its gameplay but also because of its feeling of discovery mixed with the will to survive a world that definitely doesn't want you alive. I'm serious, almost everything will have you killed. :) You start the game with Wilson, a young scientist who was tricked to enter the world of Don't Starve by a voice inside a machine, but soon you'll realize that he isn't the only playable character, some others are unlockable trough experience points which are gained once you die or once you beat the game. (Believe me you'll unlock almost all of them by dying, A LOT.).All those characters are connected by a story, a story of magic and shadows. Each character has its own perks and downfalls which brings a lot of variety to the game itself!In my humble opinion Klei did and is still doing an amazing job with this game. After all this years we are still getting updates like Reign of Giants or the new stand alone Don't Starve Together which is a fantastic experience for both veteran and new players. Added to all of this Don't Starve has a unique (and beautiful) art work sided with a fitting soundtrack. Reader, if you like survival games and you still didn't get this gem the only thing I can truly say to you is that you're missing a lot. Thank you for your time reading this!!(10/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Don't Starve is was the first game I ever got into pre-release, and now I'm still playing it. I'm hoping to get the DLC, Reign of Giants, soon, and I know I'm going to play and love the heck out of it, as well as Don't Starve Together. It can be played and replayed over and over, which cannot be said about a lot of other survival-based games. It was a wonderful soundtrack, and encorperated ideas into its gameplay that I don't think any other game could get away with.The only little thing that I think could be improved upon, (and I've heard this has already been worked on in RoG) is the storyline. The game has a sort of half-developed storyline to explain the general premise of the game, but it doesn't continue after the brief intro or before Adventure mode, which is the majority of the game. I think a few small cut-scenes, or some dialogue, or even just some hints could fix this no-problem.Don't Starve is great, because for once there is a realistic, or in some instances not so very realistic, survival game, that tests the boundaries of what makes good gameplay, and is just spot-on. It isn't the same repetitive old collecting resource and killing monster crud that you get over and over with every low-graphical survival game that becomes popular, but rather it takes that and makes it, throws half of it away, and replaces that with a beautiful, and dark, atmostphere. I think this game is a must-get for any survival, fantasy, or general PC gamer.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Don't Starve is...It's really amazing, to be simple about it. It's one of those games that can make you as angry as you've ever been without driving you away. I'll go ahead and get to the point.Don't Starve in and of itself is a great concept, simple at face but so very intricate and complex in the inner mechanisms. You'll find yourself dying multiple times due to your sheer overconfidence, feeling like you've judged the situation properly but dying due to your own malfunctions. There's so much to do, so many different ways to survive, and a huge open world that's generated differently each time in front of you. You can change and edit the world you wish to explore to your own standards, which is amazing. The crafting mechanic is really well made and I love that you have to build higher tiers to get better things. The sanity is so easily overlooked until the moment when everything starts going grey and the monsters from your mind start trying to murder you. There's so much in this game, and it's all really, really wonderful. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
 Don't Starve  A game developed by Klei Entertainment that brings you a Survival game like no other; with a very unique art style that (I quote) , "Resembles Tim Burton's conceptual art", and 3D props in a 2D terrain, Which many gamers (Including myself) have found pleasant to the eyes, either they're fans or not of this odd, eerie, but still cool style. The game has this aspect that I believe is essential in every survival game, and it is that it puts you right into the world; with no tutorials, no resources, no help, whatsoever (Only if you dont read any internet guides). The game wants you dead, and the fact of being clueless about the wilderness surrounding you serves as a motivation to keep exploring, crafting, and knowing more details to increase your survivability. In the end, that's where the fun is at.I would tell you more about these details within the game mechanics, but that would just ruin a great part of your gameplay, which is, DISCOVERING and DYING... a lot. The audio -though being original, fitting, and makes experience to be more immersive- through the game you find it repeating itself in several occations. This could be improved if more diverse audio files were added to the already existing one. Maybe in the future this might be changed.The community is oftenly putting their creativity on display at the Don't Starve community workshop, which helps your game expand through mods and more cool stuff that other users have to offer.Another thing worth mentioning is that Klei will be releasing Don't Starve Together, allowing you to join efforts with your friends to not die that much; It doubles the fun you know.Overall, Dont Starve is a great game, with an interesting backstory for the character(s) and the game in general, amazing graphic style, well-thought mechanics, and personally, I find some elements of the game as pretty hilarious.I highly recommend it for gamers interested in the genre or even those looking to play something different but that'll bring hours of entertainment. I give it  9/10. Have fun... and remember, DON'T STARVE.

												Don't Starve is a fun little sandbox-type survival game that's been all the rage lately. However, Don't Starve takes the survival aspect a lot more seriously, with actual different mechanics than just being another Minecraft or DayZ. I just love the sheer amount of add-ons for the game created by fans all over the world, like a bunch of tweaks to the game or cool characters from other games :). i only played the game when it was free for a week, when i started i didnt know much, but i did know that you dont want to starve. after that i told my friend about the free week gameplay and i got him adicted to the game XD. now im getting the game (possibly the DLC if i have the money) and i cant wait to get back there and continue what i started and maybe not starve like i have did a handfull of times and for one acually save maxwell, or do something along the lines of that like finally stop staying at my camp for like 10 days and for once explore the world and get those buckets of loot the game says when it loads the world :), or maybe just try and live as long as i can (my record of days survived is 28) (died because of wolves). now im going to talk about the DLC reign of giants (sorry if i spelled it wrong). now i like how theres more nature, enemies, and just a more fun expirience of the game like the wettness mechanic where it adds a mechanic on when it rains you start to get wet, and when it fills up you start to freeze to death. i love how the game adds new boss enemies like the giant cyclops deer thing that comes in the snow, or the dragonfly in the summer. now i cant wait to get the game again and play it possibly with the DLC and see what the game has to offer me again :) (hopefully some cool stuff like chester and maybe, just maybe a few touch stones)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Charmingly addictive // Recommended for survival gamers who don't want their hands held+ The longer one lives, the more XP is accumulated; characters are unlocked via XP, so unlocks can be obtained by those struggling to acclimate to the game, albeit not as quickly+ Boasts myriad environments and biomes, all of them offering a unique pallet of items and consumables+ Camera rotation is a godsend, and makes camp construction much less frustrating+ Permadeath offers a rousing incentive to succeed, particularly due to nighttime being so fatal+ Absolutely fantastic art style and animations+ Has an intricate, yet fairly intuitive, crafting system; this is greatly complemented by the mechanics of magic and scientific advancement+ Controls are practical and responsive; works very well with mouse and keyboard+ In addition to the hunger and health meters, the player must also consider the needs of the 'sanity' meter, adding further to the logistical challenge; sanity requirements can be satiated differently between the unlockable characters+ Worlds are all procedurally generated, making each experience into something refreshing and unique+ Sound design is nothing less than superb- Game can often lend itself to tedious frustrations, in large part due to the unforgiving environment and the fragile nature of the player's character- Crippling lack of a tutorial or beginner's handicaps; this will not appear as a negative to most enthusiasts of the genre, but less experienced survival gamers may find it off-putting

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Full of danger lurking around literally every turn, Don't Starve is a fantastic game. Thrown into a very unforgiving world with nothing but the clothes on your back, you must work quickly to build tools, find food, and make a shelter in the often vain attempt to survive. This game is pretty difficult, and only gets harder as the game goes on; the longer you survive, the more dangerous the world becomes and harder it is to continue.I cannot recommend this game enough to people who enjoy difficult and survival games. From plants and animals that want you dead to the very shadows and darkness of night out to get you, this game will have you huddled around just about any light source you can find in minutes. I give this game a very easy 9.5/10. In short: YOU WILL DIE.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Well, where to start?... I bought this game back when it was released as an early access title on Steam. From there it has improved and developed in so many ways that it's hard to describe...Don't Starve is a cute & sometimes a little creepy survival and crafting game. Upon starting it you're dropped in a strange and hand-painted world full of mysteries, monster and ressources. From this point you'll have to build up a base and explore the world to improve your equipment and survive against the wilderness... By discovering some in-game secrets or by plain out surviving long enough you'll unlock many different characters with certain strenghts and weaknesses... The greatest thing about this game is, that it's very content rich and open to exploration...With the two DLCs "Reign of Giants" and "Shipwrecked" even more content is added to the game. In Reign of Giants you'll have to fight far stronger enemies than before and thus develop new tactics to defend yourself from those new creatures that were added to the game. You'll also have to face new environmental threads, such as dangerous and unforgiving deserts.The newly released DLC "Shipwrecked" features the exploration of a tropical version of Don't Starve, featuring completely new bosses and items, giving the game a nice and new kind of concept and tactical approach.I certainly recommend this game to anyone whos interested in open-world survival games. Don't Starve can be very harsh and unforgiving on the player, but uppon learning from your mistakes you'll survive longer and become better and better until you finally "beat" the game. I can also recommend both of the DLCs since they are extremely well made! Have fun playing and good luck surviving!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												A disturbing, slender, and well dressed gentleman bids you to wake up, and insists you find food before nightfall. What he doesn't tell you, is that come nightfall, should you be lost in the shadows, something terrible might happen. Several days pass since the start of your adventure, and you may feel pretty good about yourself, your supplies, and your structures. Just know that nothing is permanent... nothing.In Don't Starve, you're thrown into a sandbox survival game mode immediately. There is no tutorial. Death is your tutorial. Learn from it. Your goal, to find out what your goal is. There is no hand holding. Figure it out. Because if you don't, you will enevtually die. If you find out, and are ill prepared, you will also die. Take your time, but don't waste it. There is also a door, somewhere in the world. Within it, you may find answers.I was very skeptical of this game at first. "Oh great" I said, "Another sandbox survival game. Just what we needed."Then I played it, and I was hooked. The gameplay manages to be fun, rather than tedious like so many other survival games. The art style is distinct, and reminiscent of Tim Burton's older works. Each playable character works a little differently, adding to the game's replay value.This game is like being in an abusive relationship with a sociopathic puppy. In that you never know what it wants you to do, it actively tries to make you miserable, but you can't help but love it. All in all I am very pleased with this title. I would reccommend it to anyone who enjoys survival games, structure defense games, or someone just looking for a good challenge.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												BUY THIS GAME, BETTER THEN IT LOOKS !When I first seen this game I though it looked okay, not real big on indie games. But this game is addicting as hell! Only comparison I could think of is Minecraft on the Xbox. It’s about survival and crafting. But like crafting for Minecraft on the Xbox where you don’t drag you just click and if you have what you need you successfully craft it. (does make remembering what you need to craft things a bit difficult. you could just look but if you keep checking you will waste precious time you could be using to find supplies)Not only is it super fun but you discover new things about the game every play through, but it’s also in the steam workshop! Sometimes it’s a little hard to find compatible mods but if you look in the right place there’s some pretty nice ones out there! After you learn all what the game has to offer and mess around with the mods there’s still a sweet $5 DLC with new enemies and stuff its sweet and worth it. Btw this is not a spoiler but there is an adventure mode with 5 missions in it, you’ll find in survival mode. That gives it soooooo much replay value! It will scare you, put you on the edge of your seat, and♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. But is sweet when you live longer than you ever have before.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												Let me get this out of the way. I really like this game. You can tell by the hours I have put into it. However,  I do have some...Gripes with this game. Prepare for a long, insightful review. *Please note, as of right now, this is a single player game, but multyplayer will be incorporated soon sometimes this summer. It will not affect the single player game*To make things short, I was growing tired of many a game. I needed something different, something...Difficult, but something I would enjoy. I chose this survival game above all the others fro it's....Rather overused to say it, but Tim Burton like visuals and its dark humour. Very serious games get me down somewhat, and I don't regret buying this out bit.   Simply put, you start of as Wilson, a gentleman scientist, as he is the default character you will get first. You can unlock other characters by the experience points you garner by days survived. For most of them, at least. They all have their...Perks, as it were, that differentiate themselves from other characters, so you aren't just playing as a reskinned character. As such, playstyles will vary. The cold Winter wont be as tough on Wilson because of his beard, Wendy can only do half damage, but her ghost twin sister can be the brute strength. Wigfrid is an actor who takes her role seriously, but dang, is she a good fighter. *note, 2 characters are DLC content only, Wigfrid and Webber. Yes. The DLC is completely worth it. Honestly, you won't go back to the vanilla game afterwards when you play it*The game will constantly throw challenges at you to overcome. Your main priorities are shown as 3 different symbols. Health is a heart, sanity is a brain, and hunger is your stomach. You must keep these up adequately, or suffer the consequences, though the amount you need to look after these vary somewhat on each character. Most characters have a default of 200 sanity, 150 health, and 150 hunger, so keep this in mind.  Even with this challenge to overcome, it never so much feels like a cheap shot at you. It really does feel like its your own fault for dying, which is a nice change of pace. You do need armour, you cannot just run head first into things. Fighting really does have a risk here.I said amour, didn't I? You see, in this game, you need to make things. Crafting is the key  to survival, as one expects from these games. A large majority of things you need to craft come from something called the science machine. From there you can build most things, providing you have enough materials. Don't worry. Science machines are easy to craft.Speaking of easy, you can make the default game, *which is called survival* easier on yourself, or more difficult. You can change the settings to suit your needs, such as amount of grass and twigs, *very very vital!* amount of monsters, food such as berries and so on. To get the fullest out of this game, some self control is needed to not put all the food to highest and monsters to low. It will get boring, trust me....Also, don't set everything to highest. Really. You will regret it. If you grow tired of survival, which is never ending, *if you really can survive that long* There is an Adventure mode. To clear things up, this came after survival mode, and adds several different things.   Maxwell, *the tall dapperlly fella that greets you sarcastic like every time you start a new character* will greet you as per survival mode and be on his way as quickly as he appears, and you will end up in a randomly selected location. You have to survive 5 worlds, or perhaps islands, in a sense, before you get to the ending. The first location you end up has 3 possible spawn points. Hopefully luck will be kind on you and you won't get King of Winter, a place of permanent cold.   To get to the next level, you must build a door. To build a door, you must locate all of the *things*. Things are parts of the door scattered about each level, and are often guarded by creatures called Clockworks of varying sorts. They sport a chest piece theme, if you are curious. If you can successfully locate all of the things and put them were they need to go, you can traverse to the next location, however, you can only take 4 things with you. *for instance, 20 logs, 10 twigs, 5 gold and 20 rocks* Think carefully before you go through the door, as once you go through, there is no going back.Besides the monsters, there are seasons. I keep mentioning Winter, but there is of course Summer, Spring and Autumn as well. Autumn is the easiest to start out on, and each season is roughly 15 to 20 days in length on default settings. You also have caves to wander into as well if you so desire, but they won't save you from the weather. Trust me.I've said all of this and hold these mechanics in great  regard, but what do I find rather...Not quite so good?Well, on a good note to start the bad, developer feedback is a nice feature of this game. Suggestions by players are taken into account, things are tweaked, fixed or added. It's one of the high points of Don't Starve, that such a thing is allowed to happen. The downside could be said that since things are still being added or revised all of the time, not all gameplay mechanics will be dandy. Summer for instance can be quite annoying, what with things burning up on screen, *your base and items included, fortunately nothing in your inventory* However, Summer is DLC content, but its reassuring to know the developers take time to work on their DLC. Other times the game will encounter a few glitches, but very, very few of them are game crashing or breaking. Most crashing comes from mods, which again, is a nice feature of the game. I have not yet encountered something were I would have to restart as a new character, so you are in good steed.   What else ain't so great? Well, to be honest, this will be a hit and miss to many people, but for me and those like me, the biggest problem is the story. There is very little of it.  It is there, we are not talking Minecraft or Mario levels of story. *pretty much non existent* But.....Considering the style and tone of this game, you expect something more. The developers are looking into expanding the story as far as I am aware, and what little is there in terms of story and the whole tone of the game is a great start. You know Team Fortress started with pretty much nothing? Look how far that has gone. Still much more to go, but the world they have is fantastic with all the story possibilities it could take. Don't Starve is one of those games. You really do want to know more of the bad guys story from what you learn about them. You wonder why people are being taken to this island. Why did Wilson, a scientist with little luck, got chosen to be stuck on this nightmare of a place? Why did any of them? Who are the things in the darkness? the shadows...Watching you?..... With all of this being said though, the characters you will play as do have their own personality, as you will discover when examining objects or doing general survival things. Wilson himself is rather kooky, not really using scientific terms for things...Or....any intelligible terms for many things, honestly. Willow is like a child, but like Wilson is in her early 30's, and likes...Burning things. Wendy the child speaks of death and decay, Wes...Well....he is a mime, so good luck trying to get any words out of him...At all. You'll find a character  you like here,  as there are just over 10 of them, and with the added scenario, and the darkly humorous tone to the whole game, its a joy to think of the things that could happen story wise, if the developers ever get around to it. I'm hopeful they will.   On a whole, the gameplay and mechanics have very little fault to them, most every death feels like its down to your own idiocy instead of a cheap shot, the characters likeable in their own way, the idea itself both in terms of story and gameplay intriguing and visuals great. Get this game now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												A beautiful game with a dark, gloomy art style that I personally find very appealing. Definitely one of my favorite games.It's very hard at the beginning, and still hard after getting used to it, (I still die from the most stupid things from time to time) but that's what makes the game so fun. It's unforgiving, but never unfair. Beside, you can tweak the worlds to your liking if you're having a hard time, like more food, less water, longer days, etc. Or crank up the difficulty to test your survival skills. However, I recommend playing on default setting a couple times before you start tweaking.There is a lot of different characters to choose from too, each with its own sets of abilities, like a pyromaniac little girl or a upgradable robot. There's also a little touch of dark humor that give the game quite a charm. Combine the characters with the world generation's semi-random nature and you get quite the repleyability.I recommend this game to any fans of survival/crafting games, or anyone that want to be alone on a twisted island.However, I don't recommend this game to anyone who likes to feel overpowered. Yes, the game gives you total control over yourself, but believe me, you will be overwhelmed by this game. You will die. A lot. It's not like minecraft or Terrarria where you'll respawn on death, if you die, you lose EVERYTHING. But then again, this introduce the concept of risk to the game. That's something I personally really enjoy since I feel like it gives a lots of weight to each of my decisions, but I can also see how it can be a turn off to some people, hence the warning.Hope you'll enjoy the game as much as I did.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Don't starve is one of those Indy Games that you like, play fore a while, get addicted to, play a little longer and the put it away for a year or so to start the process again later on.The way this game plays, feels and is being experienced just works for me. the art feels both safe (mainly because it is cartoony) and yet dark too. And for a game in which the dark will kill you and you'll have to create light to stay alive that is great! At night you'll be terrified while feeding your campfire with the last pieces of wood, and during the day you'll be ready for an adventure to gather supplies, food and weaponrry for the next night (and day).I must admit, after playing it for too long it will get boring. mainly because it's still an indy game which just isn't build for great scale and an unlimited supply of options (Except for the all-known Mojang Project, if you get my drift). But, after a while, you can pick it up again an loose yourself again for a couple of weeks (maybe months).For the price I would say it is definately worth it! Great and addictive to certain extend, 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												One of my great fall back games. Even before the Reign of Giants DLC the game received much love in the form of updates by the developers. In the game you start out as Wilson, you are pulled in to a bizarre world and someone named Maxwell and you basically have to survive. There are two implicit game modes (you don't have to choose they just both are there) to play. One is just the pure survival in a bizarre world and the other is to find the person who got you in the world and "deal with him "Both things are really entertaining to do. The game is hard enough as it is on its default standing but you can change any custom generated world as you please. If you don't like a world all are random generated so best start a new one. The game has its own art style you either love or hate. Its got a unique atmosphere and an isometric 3rd person view when playing the game (camera can be turned)I personally just love this game and every once in a while check what has been changed. I'd say if you like how the game looks, like a challenge, like random generated worlds, like survival games and this art style, than this game is for you!

												Don't let the small amount of time fool you, I've spent many hours in game both online and offline. I must say when it comes to survival games this has to be one of my all time favorites. I had a fasination with them back in the old days of WarCraft 3 Wilderness survival. At first this game appeared as a typical collect stuff, Build, Eat, survive. But, it offers so much more and with a unique twist using your characters sanity. The only downside is getting started is a little overwhelming as there is so much to be done (In no particular order).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												This game probably doesn't need another positive review, but I've been having fun with, so I'll add one.  It is essentially a survival crafting game where you try to outsmart the world (which is constantly trying to kill you) in order to live as long as possible and discover it's secrets.  The best aspect of this game is discovering secrets, so play without instruction and discover all these secrets for yourself.  It seems simplistic in the first few hours; then you realize there are lots of fun surprises that let you overcome seemingly impossible obstacles.You will probably die a lot in this process.  And when you die, you start over.  It can get frustrating.  But if you put it down for a while, you will want to come back to it.  The game would have benefited from 'undefined' achievements; e.g. achievements where you don't have instructions on how to achieve them.  This would provide a record of what you have discovered without giving you a grindy laundry list of things to do and wouldn't make you play for the wrong reasons.  The developers (and particularly the forum mod) have a strange attitude of not allowing discussion of development decisions on this topic and others, which is off-putting for those who like to discuss the games they play, but it does not directly impact the enjoyability the game itself.It's a lot of fun, has a great art style, and definitely worth playing.  I only hope it doesn't get too repetitive before I'm able to survive adventure mode.

												This game is fun to play in short bursts.  It's relatively easy to get into and start learning, but the finer points of survival take time to figure out.  I really dig the aesthetic, and all the little sound design touches.  The different playable characters you unlock add a good bit of variety.  It can get a little monotonous once you've sorta figured everything out, though.  Long-term survival means needing to do as little as is possible in as regular a routine as is possible, so naturally it sorta equals out to boredom in the end.  But that's cool, just go die and start over.
